column5: and he will have b hours to study tomorrow. Note that it is possible that on his planet there are more hours in a day than on Earth. Lesha knows that the quality of his knowledge will only depend on the number of lecture notes he will read. He has access to an infinite number of notes that are enumerated with positive integers
column6: but he knows that he can read the first note in one hour
column7: the second note in two hours and so on. In other words
column8: Lesha can read the note with number k in k hours. Lesha can read the notes in arbitrary order
column9: however
column10: he can\'t start reading a note in the first day and finish its reading in the second day.Thus
column11: the student has to fully read several lecture notes today
column12: spending at most a hours in total
column13: and fully read several lecture notes tomorrow
column14: spending at most b hours in total. What is the maximum number of notes Lesha can read in the remaining time? Which notes should he read in the first day
column15: and whichï¿½\xe2\x80\x94 in the second?" 1600

column3: greedy" "Let\'s consider a simplified version of order book of some stock. The order book is a list of orders (offers) from people that want to buy or sell one unit of the stock
column4: each order is described by direction (BUY or SELL) and price.At every moment of time
column5: every SELL offer has higher price than every BUY offer. In this problem no two ever existed orders will have the same price.The lowest-price SELL order and the highest-price BUY order are called the best offers
column6: marked with black frames on the picture below.  The presented order book says that someone wants to sell the product at price 1212 and it\'s the best SELL offer because the other two have higher prices. The best BUY offer has price 1010. There are two possible actions in this orderbook:  Somebody adds a new order of some direction with some price. Somebody accepts the best possible SELL or BUY offer (makes a deal). It\'s impossible to accept not the best SELL or BUY offer (to make a deal at worse price). After someone accepts the offer
column7: it is removed from the orderbook forever.It is allowed to add new BUY order only with prices less than the best SELL offer (if you want to buy stock for higher price
column8: then instead of adding an order you should accept the best SELL offer). Similarly
column9: one couldn\'t add a new SELL order with price less or equal to the best BUY offer. For example
column10: you can\'t add a new offer ""SELL 2020"" if there is already an offer ""BUY 2020"" or ""BUY 2525""ï¿½\xe2\x80\x94 in this case you just accept the best BUY offer.You have a damaged order book log (in the beginning the are no orders in book). Every action has one of the two types: ""ADD pp"" denotes adding a new order with price pp and unknown direction. The order must not contradict with orders still not removed from the order book.  ""ACCEPT pp"" denotes accepting an existing best offer with price pp and unknown direction.The directions of all actions are lost. Information from the log isn\'t always enough to determine these directions. Count the number of ways to correctly restore all ADD action directions so that all the described conditions are satisfied at any moment. Since the answer could be large
column11: output it modulo 109+7109+7. If it is impossible to correctly restore directions
column12: then output 00." 2100

column1: 1025F "Disjoint Triangles" geometry "A point belongs to a triangle if it lies inside the triangle or on one of its sides. Two triangles are disjoint if there is no point on the plane that belongs to both triangles.You are given n points on the plane. No two points coincide and no three points are collinear.Find the number of different ways to choose two disjoint triangles with vertices in the given points. Two ways which differ only in order of triangles or in order of vertices inside triangles are considered equal." 2700

column1: 1023C "Bracket Subsequence" greedy "A bracket sequence is a string containing only characters ""("" and "")"". For example
column2: bracket sequences ""()()"" and ""(())"" are regular (the resulting expressions are: ""(1)+(1)"" and ""((1+1)+1)"")
column4: ""("" and "")"" are not.Subsequence is a sequence that can be derived from another sequence by deleting some elements without changing the order of the remaining elements.You are given a regular bracket sequence s and an integer number k. Your task is to find a regular bracket sequence of length exactly k such that it is also a subsequence of s.It is guaranteed that such sequence always exists." 1200

column3: math "You received a notebook which is called Death Note. This notebook has infinite number of pages. A rule is written on the last page (huh) of this notebook. column4: who wouldn\'t get scared if he just receive a notebook which is named Death Note with a some strange rule written in it?).Of course
column5: you decided to follow this rule. When you calmed down
column6: you came up with a strategy how you will write names in the notebook. You have calculated that each page of the notebook can contain exactly m names. You will start writing names from the first page. You will write names on the current page as long as the limit on the number of names on this page is not exceeded. When the current page is over
column7: you turn the page. Note that you always turn the page when it ends
column8: it doesn\'t matter if it is the last day or not. If after some day the current page still can hold at least one name
column9: during the next day you will continue writing the names from the current page.Now you are interested in the following question: how many times will you turn the page during each day? You are interested in the number of pages you will turn each day from 1 to n." 900

column4: print ""-1"". Otherwise print the minimum number of songs Ivan needs to compress." 1100

column3: trees "The Main Martian Tree grows on Mars. It is a binary tree (a rooted tree
column4: with no more than two sons at each vertex) with nn vertices
column5: where the root vertex has the number 11. Its fruits are the Main Martian Fruits. It\'s summer now
column6: so this tree does not have any fruit yet.Autumn is coming soon
column7: and leaves and branches will begin to fall off the tree. It is clear
column8: that if a vertex falls off the tree
column9: then its entire subtree will fall off too. In addition
column10: the root will remain on the tree. Formally: the tree will have some connected subset of vertices containing the root.After that
column11: the fruits will grow on the tree (only at those vertices which remain). Exactly xx fruits will grow in the root. The number of fruits in each remaining vertex will be not less than the sum of the numbers of fruits in the remaining sons of this vertex. It is allowed
column12: that some vertices will not have any fruits.Natasha wondered how many tree configurations can be after the described changes. Since this number can be very large
column13: output it modulo 998244353998244353.Two configurations of the resulting tree are considered different if one of these two conditions is true: they have different subsets of remaining vertices; they have the same subset of remaining vertices
column14: but there is a vertex in this subset where they have a different amount of fruits." 3400

column1: 1010C Border "number theory" "Astronaut Natasha arrived on Mars. She knows that the Martians are very poor aliens. To ensure a better life for the Mars citizens

column3: therefore she had to pay the tax to enter the territory of Mars.There are n banknote denominations on Mars: the value of i-th banknote is ai. Natasha has an infinite number of banknotes of each denomination.Martians have k fingers on their hands
column4: so they use a number system with base k. In addition
column5: the Martians consider the digit d (in the number system with base k) divine. Thus
column6: if the last digit in Natasha\'s tax amount written in the number system with the base k is d
column7: the Martians will be happy. Unfortunately
column8: Natasha does not know the Martians\' divine digit yet.Determine for which values d Natasha can make the Martians happy.Natasha can use only her banknotes. Martians don\'t give her change." 1800

However

column3: probabilities "Leha is planning his journey from Moscow to Saratov. He hates trains
column4: so he has decided to get from one city to another by car.The path from Moscow to Saratov can be represented as a straight line (well
column5: it\'s not that straight in reality
column6: but in this problem we will consider it to be straight)
column7: and the distance between Moscow and Saratov is n km. Let\'s say that Moscow is situated at the point with coordinate 0 km
column8: and Saratov \xe2\x80\x94 at coordinate n km.Driving for a long time may be really difficult. Formally
column9: if Leha has already covered i kilometers since he stopped to have a rest
column10: he considers the difficulty of covering (i+1)-th kilometer as ai+1. It is guaranteed that for every i\xe2\x88\x88[1
column11: n\xe2\x88\x921] ai\xe2\x89\xa4ai+1. The difficulty of the journey is denoted as the sum of difficulties of each kilometer in the journey.Fortunately
column12: there may be some rest sites between Moscow and Saratov. Every integer point from 1 to n\xe2\x88\x921 may contain a rest site. When Leha enters a rest site
column13: he may have a rest
column14: and the next kilometer will have difficulty a1
column15: the kilometer after it \xe2\x80\x94 difficulty a2
column16: and so on.For example
column17: if n=5 and there is a rest site in coordinate 2
column18: the difficulty of journey will be 2a1+2a2+a3: the first kilometer will have difficulty a1
column19: the second one \xe2\x80\x94 a2
column20: then Leha will have a rest
column21: and the third kilometer will have difficulty a1
column22: the fourth \xe2\x80\x94 a2
column23: and the last one \xe2\x80\x94 a3. Another example: if n=7 and there are rest sites in coordinates 1 and 5
column24: the difficulty of Leha\'s journey is 3a1+2a2+a3+a4.Leha doesn\'t know which integer points contain rest sites. So he has to consider every possible situation. Obviously
column25: there are 2n\xe2\x88\x921 different distributions of rest sites (two distributions are different if there exists some point x such that it contains a rest site in exactly one of these distributions). Leha considers all these distributions to be equiprobable. He wants to calculate p \xe2\x80\x94 the expected value of difficulty of his journey.Obviously
column26: p\xe2\x8b\x852n\xe2\x88\x921 is an integer number. You have to calculate it modulo 998244353." 2000

column16: the bill disappears

column20: then he buys the fourth game using the bill of value a2 (the third bill becomes the first one in Maxim\'s wallet) and buys the fifth game using the bill of value a3.Your task is to get the number of games Maxim will buy." 800

column3: trees" "In this problem you will have to help Berland army with organizing their command delivery system.There are nn officers in Berland army. The first officer is the commander of the army
column4: and he does not have any superiors. Every other officer has exactly one direct superior. If officer aa is the direct superior of officer bb
column5: then we also can say that officer bb is a direct subordinate of officer aa.Officer xx is considered to be a subordinate (direct or indirect) of officer yy if one of the following conditions holds:  officer yy is the direct superior of officer xx;  the direct superior of officer xx is a subordinate of officer yy. For example
column6: on the picture below the subordinates of the officer 33 are: 5
column14: 9.The structure of Berland army is organized in such a way that every officer
column15: except for the commander
column16: is a subordinate of the commander of the army.Formally
column17: let\'s represent Berland army as a tree consisting of nn vertices
column18: in which vertex uu corresponds to officer uu. The parent of vertex uu corresponds to the direct superior of officer uu. The root (which has index 11) corresponds to the commander of the army.Berland War Ministry has ordered you to give answers on qq queries
column19: the ii-th query is given as (ui
column20: ki)(ui
column21: ki)
column22: where uiui is some officer
column23: and kiki is a positive integer.To process the ii-th query imagine how a command from uiui spreads to the subordinates of uiui. Typical DFS (depth first search) algorithm is used here.Suppose the current officer is aa and he spreads a command. Officer aa chooses bb \xe2\x80\x94 one of his direct subordinates (i.e. a child in the tree) who has not received this command yet. If there are many such direct subordinates
column24: then aa chooses the one having minimal index. Officer aa gives a command to officer bb. Afterwards
column25: bb uses exactly the same algorithm to spread the command to its subtree. After bb finishes spreading the command
column26: officer aa chooses the next direct subordinate again (using the same strategy). When officer aa cannot choose any direct subordinate who still hasn\'t received this command
column27: officer aa finishes spreading the command.Let\'s look at the following example:  If officer 11 spreads a command
column28: officers receive it in the following order: [1
column45: officers receive it in the following order: [3
column56: officers receive it in the following order: [7
column59: officers receive it in the following order: [9][9].To answer the ii-th query (ui
column62: construct a sequence which describes the order in which officers will receive the command if the uiui-th officer spreads it. Return the kiki-th element of the constructed list or -1 if there are fewer than kiki elements in it.You should process queries independently. A query doesn\'t affect the following queries." 1600

You are allowed to do the following changes:   Choose any index i (1\xe2\x89\xa4i\xe2\x89\xa4n) and swap characters ai and bi;  Choose any index i (1\xe2\x89\xa4i\xe2\x89\xa4n) and swap characters ai and an\xe2\x88\x92i+1;  Choose any index i (1\xe2\x89\xa4i\xe2\x89\xa4n) and swap characters bi and bn\xe2\x88\x92i+1. Also you can swap two equal characters but this operation is useless as well.You have to make these strings equal by applying any number of changes described above

column1: 1006A "Adjacent Replacements" implementation "Mishka got an integer array a of length n as a birthday present (what a surprise!).Mishka doesn\'t like this present and wants to change it somehow. He has invented an algorithm and called it ""Mishka\'s Adjacent Replacements Algorithm"". This algorithm can be represented as a sequence of steps:  Replace each occurrence of 1 in the array a with 2;  Replace each occurrence of 2 in the array a with 1;  Replace each occurrence of 3 in the array a with 4;  Replace each occurrence of 4 in the array a with 3;  Replace each occurrence of 5 in the array a with 6;  Replace each occurrence of 6 in the array a with 5;  \xe2\x80\xa6  Replace each occurrence of 109\xe2\x88\x921 in the array a with 109;  Replace each occurrence of 109 in the array a with 109\xe2\x88\x921. Note that the dots in the middle of this algorithm mean that Mishka applies these replacements for each pair of adjacent integers (2i\xe2\x88\x921
column4: \xe2\x80\xa6
column5: 5\xe2\x8b\x85108} as described above.For example
column6: for the array a=[1
column11: the following sequence of arrays represents the algorithm: [1
column15: 10] \xe2\x86\x92 (replace all occurrences of 1 with 2) \xe2\x86\x92 [2
column19: 10] \xe2\x86\x92 (replace all occurrences of 2 with 1) \xe2\x86\x92 [1
column23: 10] \xe2\x86\x92 (replace all occurrences of 3 with 4) \xe2\x86\x92 [1
column31: 10] \xe2\x86\x92 (replace all occurrences of 5 with 6) \xe2\x86\x92 [1

column47: 9]. The later steps of the algorithm do not change the array.Mishka is very lazy and he doesn\'t want to apply these changes by himself. But he is very interested in their result. Help him find it." 800

column3: number theory" "Polycarp likes numbers that are divisible by 3.He has a huge number s. Polycarp wants to cut from it the maximum number of numbers that are divisible by 3. To do this
column4: he makes an arbitrary number of vertical cuts between pairs of adjacent digits. As a result
column5: after m such cuts
column6: there will be m+1 parts in total. Polycarp analyzes each of the obtained numbers and finds the number of those that are divisible by 3.For example
column7: if the original number is s=3121
column8: then Polycarp can cut it into three parts with two cuts: 3|1|21. As a result
column9: he will get two numbers that are divisible by 3.Polycarp can make an arbitrary number of vertical cuts
column10: where each cut is made between a pair of adjacent digits. The resulting numbers cannot contain extra leading zeroes (that is
column11: the number can begin with 0 if and only if this number is exactly one character \'0\'). For example
column13: 01 and 00099 are not valid numbers
column14: but 90
column15: 0 and 10001 are valid.What is the maximum number of numbers divisible by 3 that Polycarp can obtain?" 1500

column1: 1003D "Coins and Queries" greedy "Polycarp has n coins
column2: the value of the i-th coin is ai. It is guaranteed that all the values are integer powers of 2 (i.e. ai=2d for some non-negative integer number d).Polycarp wants to know answers on q queries. The j-th query is described as integer number bj. The answer to the query is the minimum number of coins that is necessary to obtain the value bj using some subset of coins (Polycarp can use only coins he has). If Polycarp can\'t obtain the value bj
column3: the answer to the j-th query is -1.The queries are independent (the answer on the query doesn\'t affect Polycarp\'s coins)." 1600
math" "The heat during the last few days has been really intense. Scientists from all over the Berland study how the temperatures and weather change
column4: and they claim that this summer is abnormally hot. But any scientific claim sounds a lot more reasonable if there are some numbers involved
column5: so they have decided to actually calculate some value which would represent how high the temperatures are.Mathematicians of Berland State University came up with a special heat intensity value. This value is calculated as follows:Suppose we want to analyze the segment of n consecutive days. We have measured the temperatures during these n days; the temperature during i-th day equals ai.We denote the average temperature of a segment of some consecutive days as the arithmetic mean of the temperature measures during this segment of days. So
column6: if we want to analyze the average temperature from day x to day y
column7: we calculate it as y\xe2\x88\x91i=xaiy\xe2\x88\x92x+1 (note that division is performed without any rounding). The heat intensity value is the maximum of average temperatures over all segments of not less than k consecutive days. For example
column8: if analyzing the measures [3
column11: 2] and k=3
column12: we are interested in segments [3
column17: 2] and [3
column20: 2] (we want to find the maximum value of average temperature over these segments).You have been hired by Berland State University to write a program that would compute the heat intensity value of a given period of days. Are you up to this task?" 1300

column3: trees" "You are given a weighted tree (undirected connected graph with no cycles
column4: loops or multiple edges) with n vertices. The edge {uj
column5: vj} has weight wj. Also each vertex i has its own value ai assigned to it.Let\'s call a path starting in vertex u and ending in vertex v
column6: where each edge can appear no more than twice (regardless of direction)
column7: a 2-path. Vertices can appear in the 2-path multiple times (even start and end vertices).For some 2-path p profit Pr(p)=\xe2\x88\x91v\xe2\x88\x88distinct vertices inï¿½pav\xe2\x88\x92\xe2\x88\x91e\xe2\x88\x88distinct edges inï¿½pke\xe2\x8b\x85we
column8: where ke is the number of times edge e appears in p. That is
column9: vertices are counted once
column10: but edges are counted the number of times they appear in p.You are about to answer m queries. Each query is a pair of vertices (qu
column11: qv). For each query find 2-path p from qu to qv with maximal profit Pr(p)." 2700

column2: divide and conquer" "You are given an array a consisting of n integers
column3: and q queries to it. i-th query is denoted by two integers li and ri. For each query
column4: you have to find any integer that occurs exactly once in the subarray of a from index li to index ri (a subarray is a contiguous subsegment of an array). For example
column5: if a=[1
column11: then for query (li=2
column12: ri=6) the subarray we are interested in is [1
column17: and possible answers are 1
column18: 3 and 4; for query (li=1
column19: ri=2) the subarray we are interested in is [1
column21: and there is no such element that occurs exactly once.Can you answer all of the queries?" 2400

column3: trees" "Your friend is developing a computer game. He has already decided how the game world should look like \xe2\x80\x94 it should consist of n locations connected by m two-way passages. The passages are designed in such a way that it should be possible to get from any location to any other location.Of course
column4: some passages should be guarded by the monsters (if you just can go everywhere without any difficulties
column5: then it\'s not fun
column6: right?). Some crucial passages will be guarded by really fearsome monsters
column7: requiring the hero to prepare for battle and designing his own tactics of defeating them (commonly these kinds of monsters are called bosses). And your friend wants you to help him place these bosses.The game will start in location s and end in location t
column8: but these locations are not chosen yet. After choosing these locations
column9: your friend will place a boss in each passage such that it is impossible to get from s to t without using this passage. Your friend wants to place as much bosses as possible (because more challenges means more fun
column10: right?)
column11: so he asks you to help him determine the maximum possible number of bosses
column12: considering that any location can be chosen as s or as t." 2100

column3: sortings" "You are given n segments on a coordinate line; each endpoint of every segment has integer coordinates. Some segments can degenerate to points. Segments can intersect with each other
column4: be nested in each other or even coincide.Your task is the following: for every k\xe2\x88\x88[1..n]
column5: calculate the number of points with integer coordinates such that the number of segments that cover these points equals k. A segment with endpoints li and ri covers point x if and only if li\xe2\x89\xa4x\xe2\x89\xa4ri." 1700

column2: you bought a brand new smart lamp with programming features. At first
column3: you set up a schedule to the lamp. Every day it will turn power on at moment 0 and turn power off at moment M. Moreover
column4: the lamp allows you to set a program of switching its state (states are ""lights on"" and ""lights off""). Unfortunately
column5: some program is already installed into the lamp.The lamp allows only good programs. Good program can be represented as a non-empty array a
column6: where 0<a1<a2<\xe2\x8b\xaf<a|a|<M. All ai must be integers. Of course
column7: preinstalled program is a good program.The lamp follows program a in next manner: at moment 0 turns power and light on. Then at moment ai the lamp flips its state to opposite (if it was lit
column8: it turns off
column9: and vice versa). The state of the lamp flips instantly: for example
column10: if you turn the light off at moment 1 and then do nothing
column11: the total time when the lamp is lit will be 1. Finally
column12: at moment M the lamp is turning its power off regardless of its state.Since you are not among those people who read instructions
column13: and you don\'t understand the language it\'s written in
column14: you realize (after some testing) the only possible way to alter the preinstalled program. You can insert at most one element into the program a
column15: so it still should be a good program after alteration. Insertion can be done between any pair of consecutive elements of a
column16: or even at the begining or at the end of a.Find such a way to alter the program that the total time when the lamp is lit is maximum possible. Maybe you should leave program untouched. If the lamp is lit from x till moment y
column17: then its lit for y\xe2\x88\x92x units of time. Segments of time when the lamp is lit are summed up." 1500

column2: implementation "Codehorses has just hosted the second Codehorses Cup. This year
column3: the same as the previous one
column4: organizers are giving T-shirts for the winners.The valid sizes of T-shirts are either ""M"" or from 0 to 3 ""X"" followed by ""S"" or ""L"". For example
column5: sizes ""M""
column6: ""XXS""
column8: ""XXXL"" are valid and ""XM""
column10: ""XXXXL"" are not.There are n winners to the cup for both the previous year and the current year. Ksenia has a list with the T-shirt sizes printed for the last year cup and is yet to send the new list to the printing office. Organizers want to distribute the prizes as soon as possible
column11: so now Ksenia is required not to write the whole list from the scratch but just make some changes to the list of the previous year. In one second she can choose arbitrary position in any word and replace its character with some uppercase Latin letter. Ksenia can\'t remove or add letters in any of the words.What is the minimal number of seconds Ksenia is required to spend to change the last year list to the current one?The lists are unordered. That means
column12: two lists are considered equal if and only if the number of occurrences of any string is the same in both lists." 1200

column1: 999F "Cards and Joy" dp "There are n players sitting at the card table. Each player has a favorite number. The favorite number of the j-th player is fj.There are k\xe2\x8b\x85n cards on the table. Each card contains a single integer: the i-th card contains number ci. Also
column2: you are given a sequence h1
column3: h2
column4: \xe2\x80\xa6
column5: hk. Its meaning will be explained below.The players have to distribute all the cards in such a way that each of them will hold exactly k cards. After all the cards are distributed
column6: each player counts the number of cards he has that contains his favorite number. The joy level of a player equals ht if the player holds t cards containing his favorite number. If a player gets no cards with his favorite number (i.e.
column8: his joy level is 0.Print the maximum possible total joy levels of the players after the cards are distributed. Note that the sequence h1
column9: \xe2\x80\xa6
column10: hk is the same for all the players." 2000

column1: 999C "Alphabetic Removals" implementation "You are given a string s consisting of n lowercase Latin letters. Polycarp wants to remove exactly k characters (k\xe2\x89\xa4n) from the string s. Polycarp uses the following algorithm k times:  if there is at least one letter \'a\'
column2: remove the leftmost occurrence and stop the algorithm
column3: otherwise go to next item;  if there is at least one letter \'b\'
column4: remove the leftmost occurrence and stop the algorithm
column5: otherwise go to next item;  ...  remove the leftmost occurrence of the letter \'z\' and stop the algorithm. This algorithm removes a single letter from the string. Polycarp performs this algorithm exactly k times

column1: 979E "Kuro and Topological Parity" dp "Kuro has recently won the ""Most intelligent cat ever"" contest. The three friends then decided to go to Katie\'s home to celebrate Kuro\'s winning. After a big meal
column2: they took a small break then started playing games.Kuro challenged Katie to create a game with only a white paper
column3: a pencil
column4: a pair of scissors and a lot of arrows (you can assume that the number of arrows is infinite). Immediately
column5: Katie came up with the game called Topological Parity.The paper is divided into nn pieces enumerated from 11 to nn. Shiro has painted some pieces with some color. Specifically
column6: the ii-th piece has color cici where ci=0ci=0 defines black color
column7: ci=1ci=1 defines white color and ci=\xe2\x88\x921ci=\xe2\x88\x921 means that the piece hasn\'t been colored yet.The rules of the game is simple. Players must put some arrows between some pairs of different pieces in such a way that for each arrow
column8: the number in the piece it starts from is less than the number of the piece it ends at. Also
column9: two different pieces can only be connected by at most one arrow. After that the players must choose the color (00 or 11) for each of the unpainted pieces. The score of a valid way of putting the arrows and coloring pieces is defined as the number of paths of pieces of alternating colors. For example
column13: [0][0] are valid paths and will be counted. You can only travel from piece xx to piece yy if and only if there is an arrow from xx to yy.But Kuro is not fun yet. He loves parity. Let\'s call his favorite parity pp where p=0p=0 stands for ""even"" and p=1p=1 stands for ""odd"". He wants to put the arrows and choose colors in such a way that the score has the parity of pp.It seems like there will be so many ways which satisfy Kuro. He wants to count the number of them but this could be a very large number. Let\'s help him with his problem
column14: but print it modulo 109+7109+7." 2400

column1: 979B "Treasure Hunt" greedy "After the big birthday party

column4: she invited her best friends Kuro and Shiro to play with her.The three friends are very smart so they passed all the challenges very quickly and finally reached the destination. column5: Kuro came up with some ribbons.A random colorful ribbon is given to each of the cats. Each color of the ribbon can be represented as an uppercase or lowercase Latin letter. Let\'s call a consecutive subsequence of colors that appears in the ribbon a subribbon. The beauty of a ribbon is defined as the maximum number of times one of its subribbon appears in the ribbon. The more the subribbon appears
column6: the more beautiful is the ribbon. For example

column8: and the ribbon abcdabc has the beauty of 2 because its subribbon abc appears twice.The rules are simple. The game will have n turns. Every turn
column9: each of the cats must change strictly one color (at one position) in his/her ribbon to an arbitrary color which is different from the unchanged one. For example
column10: a ribbon aaab can be changed into acab in one turn. The one having the most beautiful ribbon after n turns wins the treasure.Could you find out who is going to be the winner if they all play optimally?" 1800

column3: graphs" "You are given an undirected graph consisting of n vertices and m edges. Your task is to find the number of connected components which are cycles.Here are some definitions of graph theory.An undirected graph consists of two sets: set of nodes (called vertices) and set of edges. Each edge connects a pair of vertices. All edges are bidirectional (i.e. if a vertex a is connected with a vertex b
column4: a vertex b is also connected with a vertex a). An edge can\'t connect vertex with itself
column5: there is at most one edge between a pair of vertices.Two vertices u and v belong to the same connected component if and only if there is at least one path along edges connecting u and v.A connected component is a cycle if and only if its vertices can be reordered in such a way that:  the first vertex is connected with the second vertex by an edge
column6: the second vertex is connected with the third vertex by an edge
column7: ...  the last vertex is connected with the first vertex by an edge
column8: all the described edges of a cycle are distinct. A cycle doesn\'t contain any other edges except described above. By definition any cycle contains three or more vertices.  There are 6 connected components
column9: 2 of them are cycles: [7

column1: 959C "Mahmoud and Ehab and the wrong algorithm" "constructive algorithms
column2: trees" "Mahmoud was trying to solve the vertex cover problem on trees. The problem statement is:Given an undirected tree consisting of n nodes
column3: find the minimum number of vertices that cover all the edges. Formally
column4: we need to find a set of vertices such that for each edge (u
column5: \xe2\x80\x89v) that belongs to the tree
column6: either u is in the set
column7: or v is in the set
column8: or both are in the set. Mahmoud has found the following algorithm:  Root the tree at node 1.  Count the number of nodes at an even depth. Let it be evenCnt.  Count the number of nodes at an odd depth. Let it be oddCnt.  The answer is the minimum between evenCnt and oddCnt. The depth of a node in a tree is the number of edges in the shortest path between this node and the root. The depth of the root is 0.Ehab told Mahmoud that this algorithm is wrong
column9: but he didn\'t believe because he had tested his algorithm against many trees and it worked
column10: so Ehab asked you to find 2 trees consisting of n nodes. The algorithm should find an incorrect answer for the first tree and a correct answer for the second one." 1500

column1: 958F3 "Lightsabers (hard)" fft "There used to be unrest in the Galactic Senate. Several thousand solar systems had declared their intentions to leave the Republic. But fear not! Master Heidi was able to successfully select the Jedi Knights that have restored peace in the galaxy. However
column2: she knows that evil never sleeps and a time may come when she will need to pick another group of Jedi Knights. She wants to be sure she has enough options to do so.There are n Jedi Knights
column3: each of them with a lightsaber of one of m colors. Given a number k
column4: compute the number of differently colored collections of k lightsabers that some k Jedi Knights might have. Jedi Knights with lightsabers of the same color are indistinguishable (it\'s not the person
column5: it\'s the lightsaber color that matters!)
column6: and their order does not matter; that is
column7: we consider two collections of Jedi Knights to be different if and only if their vectors of counts of lightsabers of each color (like what you were given in the easy and the medium versions) are different. We count all subsets
column8: not only contiguous subsegments of the input sequence. Output the answer modulo 1009." 2600

column6: and each part consists of contiguous elements of A.  No two parts overlap.  The total sum S of the scores of those parts is minimized (not maximized!). Output the sum S
column7: which is the encryption code." 2500

column2: trees "You\'re given a tree with n vertices rooted at 1.We say that there\'s a k-ary heap of depth m located at u if the following holds:  For m\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x891 u itself is a k-ary heap of depth 1. column1: 955E Icicles NA "Andrew\'s favourite Krakozyabra has recenly fled away and now he\'s eager to bring it back!At the moment the refugee is inside an icy cave with n icicles dangling from the ceiling located in integer coordinates numbered from 1 to n. The distance between floor and the i-th icicle is equal to ai.Andrew is free to choose an arbitrary integer point T in range from 1 to n inclusive and at time instant 0 launch a sound wave spreading into both sides (left and right) at the speed of one point per second. Any icicle touched by the wave starts falling at the same speed (that means that in a second the distance from floor to icicle decreases by one but cannot become less that zero). While distance from icicle to floor is more than zero
column2: it is considered passable; as soon as it becomes zero
column3: the icicle blocks the path and prohibits passing.Krakozyabra is initially (i.e. at time instant 0) is located at point  and starts running in the right direction at the speed of one point per second. You can assume that events in a single second happen in the following order: first Krakozyabra changes its position
column4: and only then the sound spreads and icicles fall; in particular
column5: that means that if Krakozyabra is currently at point  and the falling (i.e. already touched by the sound wave) icicle at point i is 1 point from the floor
column6: then Krakozyabra will pass it and find itself at  and only after that the icicle will finally fall and block the path.Krakozyabra is considered entrapped if there are fallen (i.e. with ai\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x890) icicles both to the left and to the right of its current position. Help Andrew find the minimum possible time it takes to entrap Krakozyabra by choosing the optimal value of T or report that this mission is impossible." 2900

column2: math "Suppose you have two strings s and t

column5: if s is abcd and t is ddcb
column6: the distance between them is 2 \xe2\x80\x94 we may replace every occurence of a with b
column7: so s becomes bbcd
column8: and then we may replace every occurence of b with d
column9: so both strings become ddcd.You are given two strings S and T. For every substring of S consisting of |T| characters you have to determine the distance between this substring and T." 2200

column5: and an\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x890.We define fk as the number of unordered pairs of vertices in the tree such that the number of edges on the simple path between them is equal to k.Calculate fk modulo 109\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x897 for every 1\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x89\xa4\xe2\x80\x89k\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x89\xa4\xe2\x80\x892n\xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x892." 2500

At this moment there are exactly ai archers located at the i-th section of this wall. You know that archer who stands at section i can shoot orcs that attack section located at distance not exceeding r
column5: that is all such sections j that |i\xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x89j|\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x89\xa4\xe2\x80\x89r. In particular
column6: r\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x890 means that archers are only capable of shooting at orcs who attack section i.Denote as defense level of section i the total number of archers who can shoot at the orcs attacking this section. Reliability of the defense plan is the minimum value of defense level of individual wall section.There is a little time left till the attack so you can\'t redistribute archers that are already located at the wall. However
column7: there is a reserve of k archers that you can distribute among wall sections in arbitrary way. You would like to achieve maximum possible reliability of the defence plan." 2000

column3: shortest paths" "Little town Nsk consists of n junctions connected by m bidirectional roads. Each road connects two distinct junctions and no two roads connect the same pair of junctions. It is possible to get from any junction to any other junction by these roads. The distance between two junctions is equal to the minimum possible number of roads on a path between them.In order to improve the transportation system
column4: the city council asks mayor to build one new road. The problem is that the mayor has just bought a wonderful new car and he really enjoys a ride from his home
column5: located near junction s to work located near junction t. Thus
column6: he wants to build a new road in such a way that the distance between these two junctions won\'t decrease. You are assigned a task to compute the number of pairs of junctions that are not connected by the road
column7: such that if the new road between these two junctions is built the distance between s and t won\'t decrease." 1600

column11: \xe2\x80\x89j) \xe2\x80\x94 only if i\xe2\x80\x89<\xe2\x80\x89x;  (i

column2: strings "You are given a string s consisting of n lowercase Latin letters. You have to type this string using your keyboard.Initially
column3: you have an empty string. Until you type the whole string
column4: you may perform the following operation:  add a character to the end of the string. Besides
column5: at most once you may perform one additional operation: copy the string and append it to itself.For example
column6: if you have to type string abcabca
column7: you can type it in 7 operations if you type all the characters one by one. However
column8: you can type it in 5 operations if you type the string abc first and then copy it and type the last character.If you have to type string aaaaaaaaa

column10: then copy the string
column11: and then type the remaining character.Print the minimum number of operations you need to type the given string." 1400

column1: 954A "Diagonal Walking" implementation "Mikhail walks on a 2D plane. He can go either up or right. You are given a sequence of Mikhail\'s moves. He thinks that this sequence is too long and he wants to make it as short as possible.In the given sequence moving up is described by character U and moving right is described by character R. Mikhail can replace any pair of consecutive moves RU or UR with a diagonal move (described as character D). After that
column2: he can go on and do some other replacements
column3: until there is no pair of consecutive moves RU or UR left.Your problem is to print the minimum possible length of the sequence of moves after the replacements." 800

column1: 952G "Puzzling Language" "constructive algorithms" "In this problem you will write a simple code generator for a 2D programming language derived from Brainfuck.The code in this language is a rectangular grid of characters \'.\' and \'X\'. The code is converted to a Brainfuck program as follows: the characters are read in the usual order (top to bottom
column3: and each \'X\' character is converted a Brainfuck instruction to be executed. The instruction is defined by the left
column4: top and right neighbors of the \'X\' character using the following conversion table:  You are given a string. Output a program in the described language which prints this string.You can download the language interpreter used for judging here: https://assets.codeforces.com/rounds/952/puzzling-interpreter.cpp (use C++11 to compile the code). Note several implementation details: The first step of the language interpretation is conversion to a Brainfuck program
column5: which is then executed. The code must be rectangular
column6: with all lines of the same length. It can have at most 10
column7: 000 lines and 10
column8: 000 columns
column9: and can have at most 500
column10: 000 \'X\' characters. The code has toroidal topology
column11: i.e. the \'X\' on the first line will have top neighbor in the last line. Brainfuck interpreter has 30000 memory cells which store integers from 0 to 255 with increment/decrement done modulo 256. Console input (
column12: command) is allowed in Brainfuck code but has no effect when executed." 2200

952C "Ravioli Sort" implementation "Everybody knows of spaghetti sort. You decided to implement an analog sorting algorithm yourself
column2: but as you survey your pantry you realize you\'re out of spaghetti! The only type of pasta you have is ravioli
column3: but you are not going to let this stop you...You come up with the following algorithm. For each number in the array ai
column4: build a stack of ai ravioli. The image shows the stack for ai\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x894.  Arrange the stacks in one row in the order in which the corresponding numbers appear in the input array. Find the tallest one (if there are several stacks of maximal height
column5: use the leftmost one). Remove it and add its height to the end of the output array. Shift the stacks in the row so that there is no gap between them. Repeat the procedure until all stacks have been removed.At first you are very happy with your algorithm
column6: but as you try it on more inputs you realize that it doesn\'t always produce the right sorted array. Turns out when two stacks of ravioli are next to each other (at any step of the process) and differ in height by two or more
column7: the top ravioli of the taller stack slides down on top of the lower stack.Given an input array
column8: figure out whether the described algorithm will sort it correctly." 1600

column1: 949E "Binary Cards" "brute force" "It is never too late to play the fancy ""Binary Cards"" game!There is an infinite amount of cards of positive and negative ranks that are used in the game. The absolute value of any card rank is a power of two
column2: i.e. each card has a rank of either 2k or \xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x892k for some integer k\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x89\xa5\xe2\x80\x890. There is an infinite amount of cards of any valid rank.At the beginning of the game player forms his deck that is some multiset (possibly empty) of cards. It is allowed to pick any number of cards of any rank but the small deck is considered to be a skill indicator. Game consists of n rounds. In the i-th round jury tells the player an integer ai. After that the player is obligated to draw such a subset of his deck that the sum of ranks of the chosen cards is equal to ai (it is allowed to not draw any cards
column3: in which case the sum is considered to be equal to zero). If player fails to do so
column4: he loses and the game is over. Otherwise
column5: player takes back all of his cards into his deck and the game proceeds to the next round. Player is considered a winner if he is able to draw the suitable set of cards in each of the rounds.Somebody told you which numbers ai the jury is going to tell you in each round. Now you want to pick a deck consisting of the minimum number of cards that allows you to win the ""Binary Cards"" game." 2700

column4: sortings" "Instructors of Some Informatics School make students go to bed.The house contains n rooms
column5: in each room exactly b students were supposed to sleep. However
column6: at the time of curfew it happened that many students are not located in their assigned rooms. The rooms are arranged in a row and numbered from 1 to n. Initially
column7: in i-th room there are ai students. All students are currently somewhere in the house
column8: therefore a1\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x89a2\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x89...\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x89an\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x89nb. Also 2 instructors live in this house.The process of curfew enforcement is the following. One instructor starts near room 1 and moves toward room n
column9: while the second instructor starts near room n and moves toward room 1. After processing current room
column10: each instructor moves on to the next one. Both instructors enter rooms and move simultaneously
column11: if n is odd
column12: then only the first instructor processes the middle room. When all rooms are processed
column13: the process ends.When an instructor processes a room
column14: she counts the number of students in the room
column15: then turns off the light
column16: and locks the room. Also
column17: if the number of students inside the processed room is not equal to b
column18: the instructor writes down the number of this room into her notebook (and turns off the light
column19: and locks the room). Instructors are in a hurry (to prepare the study plan for the next day)
column20: so they don\'t care about who is in the room
column21: but only about the number of students.While instructors are inside the rooms
column22: students can run between rooms that are not locked and not being processed. A student can run by at most d rooms
column23: that is she can move to a room with number that differs my at most d. Also
column24: after (or instead of) running each student can hide under a bed in a room she is in. In this case the instructor will not count her during the processing. In each room any number of students can hide simultaneously.Formally
column25: here is what\'s happening:  A curfew is announced
column26: at this point in room i there are ai students.  Each student can run to another room but not further than d rooms away from her initial room
column27: or stay in place. After that each student can optionally hide under a bed.  Instructors enter room 1 and room n
column28: they count students there and lock the room (after it no one can enter or leave this room).  Each student from rooms with numbers from 2 to n\xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x891 can run to another room but not further than d rooms away from her current room
column29: or stay in place. Each student can optionally hide under a bed.  Instructors move from room 1 to room 2 and from room n to room n\xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x891.  This process continues until all rooms are processed. Let x1 denote the number of rooms in which the first instructor counted the number of non-hidden students different from b
column30: and x2 be the same number for the second instructor. Students know that the principal will only listen to one complaint
column31: therefore they want to minimize the maximum of numbers xi. Help them find this value if they use the optimal strategy." 2300

column2: graphs" "BigData Inc. is a corporation that has n data centers indexed from 1 to n that are located all over the world. These data centers provide storage for client data (you can figure out that client data is really big!).Main feature of services offered by BigData Inc. is the access availability guarantee even under the circumstances of any data center having an outage. Such a guarantee is ensured by using the two-way replication. Two-way replication is such an approach for data storage that any piece of data is represented by two identical copies that are stored in two different data centers.For each of m company clients
column3: let us denote indices of two different data centers storing this client data as ci
column4: \xe2\x80\x891 and ci
column5: \xe2\x80\x892.In order to keep data centers operational and safe
column6: the software running on data center computers is being updated regularly. Release cycle of BigData Inc. is one day meaning that the new version of software is being deployed to the data center computers each day.Data center software update is a non-trivial long process
column7: that is why there is a special hour-long time frame that is dedicated for data center maintenance. During the maintenance period
column8: data center computers are installing software updates
column9: and thus they may be unavailable. Consider the day to be exactly h hours long. For each data center there is an integer uj (0\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x89\xa4\xe2\x80\x89uj\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x89\xa4\xe2\x80\x89h\xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x891) defining the index of an hour of day
column10: such that during this hour data center j is unavailable due to maintenance.Summing up everything above
column11: the condition uci
column13: \xe2\x80\x892 should hold for each client
column14: or otherwise his data may be unaccessible while data centers that store it are under maintenance.Due to occasional timezone change in different cities all over the world
column15: the maintenance time in some of the data centers may change by one hour sometimes. Company should be prepared for such situation
column16: that is why they decided to conduct an experiment
column17: choosing some non-empty subset of data centers
column18: and shifting the maintenance time for them by an hour later (i.e. if uj\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x89h\xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x891
column19: then the new maintenance hour would become 0
column20: otherwise it would become uj\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x891). Nonetheless
column21: such an experiment should not break the accessibility guarantees
column22: meaning that data of any client should be still available during any hour of a day after the data center maintenance times are changed.Such an experiment would provide useful insights
column23: but changing update time is quite an expensive procedure
column24: that is why the company asked you to find out the minimum number of data centers that have to be included in an experiment in order to keep the data accessibility guarantees." 1900

column2: math" "Dima is a beginner programmer. During his working process

Each step Dima selects a non-empty array cell with the maximum index and moves the number written in it to the nearest empty cell to the left of the selected one. The process continues until all n numbers will appear in the first n cells of the array. For example if n\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x894
column5: the array is changing as follows:  You have to write a program that allows you to determine what number will be in the cell with index x (1\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x89\xa4\xe2\x80\x89x\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x89\xa4\xe2\x80\x89n) after Dima\'s algorithm finishes." 1700

column6: down

column8: after a turn of the black player and initially the white token can be in the same point with some black point. If at some moment the white player can\'t make a move
column9: he loses. If the white player makes 10100500 moves
column10: he wins.You are to solve the following problem. You are given initial positions of all black tokens. It is guaranteed that initially all these positions are distinct. In how many places can the white token be located initially so that if both players play optimally
column11: the black player wins?" 2500

column3: trees" "In Arcady\'s garden there grows a peculiar apple-tree that fruits one time per year. Its peculiarity can be explained in following way: there are n inflorescences
column4: numbered from 1 to n. Inflorescence number 1 is situated near base of tree and any other inflorescence with number i (i\xe2\x80\x89>\xe2\x80\x891) is situated at the top of branch
column5: which bottom is pi-th inflorescence and pi\xe2\x80\x89<\xe2\x80\x89i.Once tree starts fruiting
column6: there appears exactly one apple in each inflorescence. The same moment as apples appear
column7: they start to roll down along branches to the very base of tree. Each second all apples
column8: except ones in first inflorescence simultaneously roll down one branch closer to tree base
column9: e.g. apple in a-th inflorescence gets to pa-th inflorescence. Apples that end up in first inflorescence are gathered by Arcady in exactly the same moment. Second peculiarity of this tree is that once two apples are in same inflorescence they annihilate. This happens with each pair of apples
column10: e.g. if there are 5 apples in same inflorescence in same time
column11: only one will not be annihilated and if there are 8 apples
column12: all apples will be annihilated. Thus
column13: there can be no more than one apple in each inflorescence in each moment of time.Help Arcady with counting number of apples he will be able to collect from first inflorescence during one harvest." 1500

column3: implementation" "Polycarp is currently developing a project in Vaja language and using a popular dependency management system called Vamen. From Vamen\'s point of view both Vaja project and libraries are treated projects for simplicity.A project in Vaja has its own uniqie non-empty name consisting of lowercase latin letters with length not exceeding 10 and version \xe2\x80\x94 positive integer from 1 to 106. Each project (keep in mind that it is determined by both its name and version) might depend on other projects. For sure
column4: there are no cyclic dependencies.You\'re given a list of project descriptions. The first of the given projects is the one being developed by Polycarp at this moment. Help Polycarp determine all projects that his project depends on (directly or via a certain chain). It\'s possible that Polycarp\'s project depends on two different versions of some project. In this case collision resolving is applied
column5: i.e. for each such project the system chooses the version that minimizes the distance from it to Polycarp\'s project. If there are several options
column6: the newer (with the maximum version) is preferred. This version is considered actual; other versions and their dependencies are ignored.More formal
column7: choose such a set of projects of minimum possible size that the following conditions hold:   Polycarp\'s project is chosen;  Polycarp\'s project depends (directly or indirectly) on all other projects in the set;  no two projects share the name;  for each project x that some other project in the set depends on we have either x or some y with other version and shorter chain to Polycarp\'s project chosen. In case of ties the newer one is chosen. Output all Polycarp\'s project\'s dependencies (Polycarp\'s project itself should\'t be printed) in lexicographical order." 1900

92101 Labyrinth-1 NA "You have a robot in a two-dimensional labyrinth which consists of N\xe2\x80\x89\xc3\x97\xe2\x80\x89M cells. Some pairs of cells adjacent by side are separated by a wall or a door. The labyrinth itself is separated from the outside with walls around it. Some labyrinth cells are the exits. In order to leave the labyrinth the robot should reach any exit. There are keys in some cells. Any key can open any door but after the door is opened the key stays in the lock. Thus every key can be used only once. There are no labyrinth cells that contain both a key and an exit. Also there can not be both a wall and a door between the pair of adjacent cells.Your need to write a program in abc language (see the language description below) that will lead the robot to one of the exits. Lets numerate the labyrinth rows from 0 to N\xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x891 top to bottom and the columns \xe2\x80\x93 from 0 to M\xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x891 left to right.In abc language the following primary commands are available:  move-DIR \xe2\x80\x93 move to the adjacent cell in the  direction. down increases the number of the row by 1
column2: right increases the number of the column by 1. In case there\xe2\x80\x99s a wall or a closed door in this direction
column3: nothing\xe2\x80\x99s happening.  open-DIR \xe2\x80\x93 open the door between the current cell and the adjacent one in DIR direction. In case there isn\xe2\x80\x99t any door in this direction or it\xe2\x80\x99s already been opened or the robot doesn\xe2\x80\x99t have a key
column4: nothing\xe2\x80\x99s happening. take \xe2\x80\x93 take the key in the current cell. In case there isn\xe2\x80\x99t any key or the robot has already picked it up
column5: nothing\xe2\x80\x99s happening. The robot is able to carry any number of keys. terminate \xe2\x80\x93 terminate the program. This command is not obligatory to use. In case it\xe2\x80\x99s absent the command is added at the end of the program automatically. Also
column6: there are the following control commands in abc language:   for-N OPS end \xe2\x80\x93 repeat the sequence of the OPS commands N times
column7: 0\xe2\x80\x89<\xe2\x80\x89N\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x89\xa4\xe2\x80\x89100000. Each loop counter check counts as a command fulfilled by the robot.  if-ok  OPS1  else  OPS2  endif \xe2\x80\x93 carries out the sequence of the OPS1 commands
column8: if the previous command of moving
column9: taking the key or opening the door was successful
column10: otherwise the sequence of the OPS2 commands is being carried out. Should there be no previous command run
column11: the sequence OPS1 will be carried out. If-ok check counts as a command fulfilled by the robot.  break \xe2\x80\x93 stops the current for loop.  continue \xe2\x80\x93 finishes the current for loop iterations. Note that the control and the primary commands can be fit into each other arbitrarily.The robot will fulfill your commands sequentially until it exits the labyrinth
column12: or it runs out of the commands
column13: or the terminate command is run
column14: or the quantity of the fulfilled commands exceeds the bound number 5\xc2\xb7106.In abc language each command is a separate word and should be separated from other commands with at least one space symbol.You should write a program that prints the sequence of commands leading the robot out of the labyrinth. Of course
column15: as you are a good programmer
column16: you should optimize these sequence.The number of the non-space symbols in the sequence should not exceed 107. If you succeed in finding the way out of the labyrinth i you\xe2\x80\x99ll be granted the number of points equal to:  where:   Wi \xe2\x80\x93 labyrinth\xe2\x80\x99s weight
column17: some fixed constant.  Gi \xe2\x80\x93 number of robots moves.  Oi \xe2\x80\x93 number of fulfilled commands. Note that this number includes commands like take executed in the cells with no key
column18: as well as opening commands applied to the already opened doors.  Li \xe2\x80\x93 sequence length in symbols
column19: excluding space symbols and line breaks.  Q\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x8910\xc2\xb7N\xc2\xb7M. In case your sequence doesn\xe2\x80\x99t lead the robot to the exit you\xe2\x80\x99ll be granted 0 points. Your programs result will be the sum of all Si. You should maximize this total sum.All labyrinths will be known and available to you. You can download the archive with labyrinths by any of the given links
column20: password to extract files is aimtechiscool:  https://drive.google.com/file/d/1dkIBfW_Gy6c3FJtXjMXZPMsGKRyn3pzp  https://www.dropbox.com/s/77jrplnjgmviiwt/aimmaze.zip?dl=0  https://yadi.sk/d/JNXDLeH63RzaCi In order to make local testing of your programs more convenient
column21: the program calculating your results (checker) and the labyrinth visualizer will be available. This program is written in python3 programming language
column22: that\xe2\x80\x99s why you\xe2\x80\x99re going to need python3 interpreter
column23: as well as pillow library
column24: which you can install with the following command pip3 install pillow. pip3 is a utility program for python3 package (library) installation. It will be installed automatically with the python3 interpreter.Example command to run checker and visualizer: python3 aimmaze.py maze.in robot.abc --image maze.png. The checker can be run separately of visualization: python3 aimmaze.py maze.in robot.abc. Flag --output-log will let you see the information of robots each step: python3 aimmaze.py maze.in robot.abc --output-log. Note python3 can be installed as python on your computer.To adjust image settings
column25: you can edit constants at the beginning of the program aimmaze.py." 3200

column1: 920B "Tea Queue" implementation "Recently n students from city S moved to city P to attend a programming camp.They moved there by train. In the evening
column2: all students in the train decided that they want to drink some tea. Of course
column3: no two people can use the same teapot simultaneously
column4: so the students had to form a queue to get their tea.i-th student comes to the end of the queue at the beginning of li-th second. If there are multiple students coming to the queue in the same moment
column5: then the student with greater index comes after the student with lesser index. Students in the queue behave as follows: if there is nobody in the queue before the student
column6: then he uses the teapot for exactly one second and leaves the queue with his tea; otherwise the student waits for the people before him to get their tea. If at the beginning of ri-th second student i still cannot get his tea (there is someone before him in the queue)
column7: then he leaves the queue without getting any tea. For each student determine the second he will use the teapot and get his tea (if he actually gets it)." 1200

column8: so Jamie can decide a better schedule. Output \xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x891 if ai is not in the to-do list.  undo diï¿½\xe2\x80\x94 Undo all changes that have been made in the previous di days (not including the day of this operation) At day 0

column4: \xe2\x80\x89... an of n integers. He likes to guess the greatest common divisor (gcd) of different segments of the array. Of course
column5: sometimes the guess is not correct. However
column6: Bash will be satisfied if his guess is almost correct.Suppose he guesses that the gcd of the elements in the range [l
column7: \xe2\x80\x89r] of a is x. He considers the guess to be almost correct if he can change at most one element in the segment such that the gcd of the segment is x after making the change. Note that when he guesses
column8: he doesn\'t actually change the array \xe2\x80\x94 he just wonders if the gcd of the segment can be made x. Apart from this
column9: he also sometimes makes changes to the array itself.Since he can\'t figure it out himself
column10: Bash wants you to tell him which of his guesses are almost correct. Formally
column11: you have to process q queries of one of the following forms:  1\xe2\x80\x89l\xe2\x80\x89r\xe2\x80\x89x \xe2\x80\x94 Bash guesses that the gcd of the range [l
column12: \xe2\x80\x89r] is x. Report if this guess is almost correct.  2\xe2\x80\x89i\xe2\x80\x89y \xe2\x80\x94 Bash sets ai to y. Note: The array is 1-indexed." 1900

column4: implementation" "Recenlty Luba got a credit card and started to use it. Let\'s consider n consecutive days Luba uses the card.She starts with 0 money on her account.In the evening of i-th day a transaction ai occurs. If ai\xe2\x80\x89>\xe2\x80\x890
column5: then ai bourles are deposited to Luba\'s account. If ai\xe2\x80\x89<\xe2\x80\x890
column6: then ai bourles are withdrawn. And if ai\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x890
column7: then the amount of money on Luba\'s account is checked.In the morning of any of n days Luba can go to the bank and deposit any positive integer amount of burles to her account. But there is a limitation: the amount of money on the account can never exceed d.It can happen that the amount of money goes greater than d by some transaction in the evening. In this case answer will be \xc2\xab-1\xc2\xbb.Luba must not exceed this limit
column8: and also she wants that every day her account is checked (the days when ai\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x890) the amount of money on her account is non-negative. It takes a lot of time to go to the bank
column9: so Luba wants to know the minimum number of days she needs to deposit some money to her account (if it is possible to meet all the requirements). Help her!" 1900

column3: greedy" "Vova promised himself that he would never play computer games... But recently Firestorm \xe2\x80\x94 a well-known game developing company \xe2\x80\x94 published their newest game
column4: World of Farcraft
column5: and it became really popular. Of course
column6: Vova started playing it.Now he tries to solve a quest. The task is to come to a settlement named Overcity and spread a rumor in it.Vova knows that there are n characters in Overcity. Some characters are friends to each other
column7: and they share information they got. Also Vova knows that he can bribe each character so he or she starts spreading the rumor; i-th character wants ci gold in exchange for spreading the rumor. When a character hears the rumor
column8: he tells it to all his friends
column9: and they start spreading the rumor to their friends (for free)
column10: and so on.The quest is finished when all n characters know the rumor. What is the minimum amount of gold Vova needs to spend in order to finish the quest?Take a look at the notes if you think you haven\'t understood the problem completely." 1300

column2: implementation" "Recently Luba learned about a special kind of numbers that she calls beautiful numbers. The number is called beautiful iff its binary representation consists of k\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x891 consecutive ones
column3: and then k consecutive zeroes.Some examples of beautiful numbers:   12 (110);  1102 (610);  11110002 (12010);  1111100002 (49610). More formally
column4: the number is beautiful iff there exists some positive integer k such that the number is equal to (2k\xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x891)\xe2\x80\x89*\xe2\x80\x89(2k\xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x891).Luba has got an integer number n
column5: and she wants to find its greatest beautiful divisor. Help her to find it!" 1000

column2: Bob and Carl will soon participate in a team chess tournament. Since they are all in the same team
column3: they have decided to practise really hard before the tournament. But it\'s a bit difficult for them because chess is a game for two players
column4: not three.So they play with each other according to following rules:  Alex and Bob play the first game
column5: and Carl is spectating;  When the game ends
column6: the one who lost the game becomes the spectator in the next game
column7: and the one who was spectating plays against the winner. Alex
column8: Bob and Carl play in such a way that there are no draws.Today they have played n games
column9: and for each of these games they remember who was the winner. They decided to make up a log of games describing who won each game. But now they doubt if the information in the log is correct
column10: and they want to know if the situation described in the log they made up was possible (that is
column11: no game is won by someone who is spectating if Alex
column12: Bob and Carl play according to the rules). Help them to check it!" 900

column3: two pointers" "Hands that shed innocent blood!There are n guilty people in a line
column4: the i-th of them holds a claw with length Li. The bell rings and every person kills some of people in front of him. All people kill others at the same time. Namely
column5: the i-th person kills the j-th person if and only if j\xe2\x80\x89<\xe2\x80\x89i and j\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x89\xa5\xe2\x80\x89i\xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x89Li.You are given lengths of the claws. You need to find the total number of alive people after the bell rings." 1200

column2: implementation "Jafar has n cans of cola. Each can is described by two integers: remaining volume of cola ai and can\'s capacity bi (ai \xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x89\xa4\xe2\x80\x89 bi).Jafar has decided to pour all remaining cola into just 2 cans
column3: determine if he can do this or not!" 900

matrices "A false witness that speaketh lies!You are given a sequence containing n integers. There is a variable res that is equal to 0 initially. The following process repeats k times.Choose an index from 1 to n uniformly at random. Name it x. Add to res the multiply of all ai\'s such that 1\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x89\xa4\xe2\x80\x89i\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x89\xa4\xe2\x80\x89n
column4: but i\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x89\xa0\xe2\x80\x89x. Then
column5: subtract ax by 1.You have to find expected value of res at the end of the process. It can be proved that the expected value of res can be represented as an irreducible fraction . You have to find ." 3000

column3: graph matchings
column4: trees" "Sloth is bad
column5: mkay? So we decided to prepare a problem to punish lazy guys.You are given a tree
column6: you should count the number of ways to remove an edge from it and then add an edge to it such that the final graph is a tree and has a perfect matching. Two ways of this operation are considered different if their removed edges or their added edges aren\'t the same. The removed edge and the added edge can be equal.A perfect matching is a subset of edges such that each vertex is an endpoint of exactly one of these edges." 3100

column6: so there is one more reason for you to learn Russian :)Rick and Morty like to go to the ridge High Cry for crying loudlyï¿½\xe2\x80\x94 there is an extraordinary echo. Recently they discovered an interesting acoustic characteristic of this ridge: if Rick and Morty begin crying simultaneously from different mountains
column7: their cry would be heard between these mountains up to the height equal the bitwise OR of mountains they\'ve climbed and all the mountains between them. Bitwise OR is a binary operation which is determined the following way. Consider representation of numbers x and y in binary numeric system (probably with leading zeroes) x\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x89xk... x1x0 and y\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x89yk... y1y0. Then z\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x89xï¿½|ï¿½y is defined following way: z\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x89zk... z1z0
column8: where zi\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x891
column9: if xi\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x891 or yi\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x891
column10: and zi\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x890 otherwise. In the other words
column11: digit of bitwise OR of two numbers equals zero if and only if digits at corresponding positions is both numbers equals zero. For example bitwise OR of numbers 10\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x8910102 and 9\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x8910012 equals 11\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x8910112. In programming languages C/C++/Java/Python this operation is defined as \xc2\xab|\xc2\xbb
column12: and in Pascal as \xc2\xabor\xc2\xbb.Help Rick and Morty calculate the number of ways they can select two mountains in such a way that if they start crying from these mountains their cry will be heard above these mountains and all mountains between them. column1: 868G "El Toll Caves" math "The prehistoric caves of El Toll are located in Moi\xc3\xa0 (Barcelona). You have heard that there is a treasure hidden in one of n possible spots in the caves. You assume that each of the spots has probability 1\xe2\x80\x89/\xe2\x80\x89n to contain a treasure.You cannot get into the caves yourself
column2: so you have constructed a robot that can search the caves for treasure. Each day you can instruct the robot to visit exactly k distinct spots in the caves. If none of these spots contain treasure
column3: then the robot will obviously return with empty hands. However
column4: the caves are dark
column5: and the robot may miss the treasure even when visiting the right spot. Formally
column6: if one of the visited spots does contain a treasure
column7: the robot will obtain it with probability 1\xe2\x80\x89/\xe2\x80\x892
column8: otherwise it will return empty. Each time the robot searches the spot with the treasure
column9: his success probability is independent of all previous tries (that is
column10: the probability to miss the treasure after searching the right spot x times is 1\xe2\x80\x89/\xe2\x80\x892x).What is the expected number of days it will take to obtain the treasure if you choose optimal scheduling for the robot? Output the answer as a rational number modulo 109\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x897. Formally
column11: let the answer be an irreducible fraction P\xe2\x80\x89/\xe2\x80\x89Q
column12: then you have to output . It is guaranteed that Q is not divisible by 109\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x897." 3300

column5: meet-in-the-middle" "The game of Egg Roulette is played between two players. Initially 2R raw eggs and 2C cooked eggs are placed randomly into a carton. The shells are left on so there is no way to distinguish a raw egg from a cooked egg. One at a time
column6: a player will select an egg
column7: and then smash the egg on his/her forehead. If the egg was cooked
column8: not much happens
column9: but if the egg was raw
column10: it will make quite the mess. This continues until one player has broken R raw eggs
column11: at which point that player is declared the loser and the other player wins.The order in which players take turns can be described as a string of \'A\' and \'B\' characters
column12: where the i-th character tells which player should choose the i-th egg. Traditionally
column13: players take turns going one after the other. That is
column14: they follow the ordering ""ABABAB..."". This isn\'t very fair though
column15: because the second player will win more often than the first. We\'d like you to find a better ordering for the players to take their turns. Let\'s define the unfairness of an ordering as the absolute difference between the first player\'s win probability and the second player\'s win probability. We\'re interested in orderings that minimize the unfairness. We only consider an ordering valid if it contains the same number of \'A\'s as \'B\'s.You will also be given a string S of length 2(R\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x89C) containing only \'A\'
column17: and \'?\' characters. An ordering is said to match S if it only differs from S in positions where S contains a \'?\'. Of the valid orderings that minimize unfairness
column18: how many match S?" 3300

column3: math "Ivan has an array consisting of n elements. Each of the elements is an integer from 1 to n.Recently Ivan learned about permutations and their lexicographical order. column2: implementation "Ilya is working for the company that constructs robots. Ilya writes programs for entertainment robots
column3: and his current project is ""Bob""
column4: a new-generation game robot. Ilya\'s boss wants to know his progress so far. Especially he is interested if Bob is better at playing different games than the previous model
column5: ""Alice"". So now Ilya wants to compare his robots\' performance in a simple game called ""1-2-3"". This game is similar to the ""Rock-Paper-Scissors"" game: both robots secretly choose a number from the set {1
column7: \xe2\x80\x893} and say it at the same moment. If both robots choose the same number
column8: then it\'s a draw and noone gets any points. But if chosen numbers are different
column9: then one of the robots gets a point: 3 beats 2
column10: 2 beats 1 and 1 beats 3. Both robots\' programs make them choose their numbers in such a way that their choice in (i\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x891)-th game depends only on the numbers chosen by them in i-th game. Ilya knows that the robots will play k games
column11: Alice will choose number a in the first game
column12: and Bob will choose b in the first game. He also knows both robots\' programs and can tell what each robot will choose depending on their choices in previous game. Ilya doesn\'t want to wait until robots play all k games
column13: so he asks you to predict the number of points they will have after the final game." 1800

column3: sortings" "Vadim is really keen on travelling. Recently he heard about kayaking activity near his town and became very excited about it
column4: so he joined a party of kayakers.Now the party is ready to start its journey
column5: but firstly they have to choose kayaks. There are 2\xc2\xb7n people in the group (including Vadim)
column6: and they have exactly n\xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x891 tandem kayaks (each of which
column7: obviously
column8: can carry two people) and 2 single kayaks. i-th person\'s weight is wi
column9: and weight is an important matter in kayaking \xe2\x80\x94 if the difference between the weights of two people that sit in the same tandem kayak is too large
column10: then it can crash. And
column11: of course
column12: people want to distribute their seats in kayaks in order to minimize the chances that kayaks will crash.Formally
column13: the instability of a single kayak is always 0
column14: and the instability of a tandem kayak is the absolute difference between weights of the people that are in this kayak. Instability of the whole journey is the total instability of all kayaks.Help the party to determine minimum possible total instability!" 1500

column2: implementation" "Let quasi-palindromic number be such number that adding some leading zeros (possible none) to it produces a palindromic string. String t is called a palindrome
column3: if it reads the same from left to right and from right to left.For example
column4: numbers 131 and 2010200 are quasi-palindromic
column5: they can be transformed to strings ""131"" and ""002010200""
column6: respectively
column7: which are palindromes.You are given some integer number x. Check if it\'s a quasi-palindromic number." 900
