column4: two pointers" "A new bus route is opened in the city . The route is a closed polygon line in the place
column5: with all segments parallel to one of the axes. m buses will operate on the route. All buses move in a loop along the route in the same direction with equal constant velocities (stopping times are negligible in this problem).Buses start their movement in the first vertex of the route with equal interval. Suppose that T is the total time for a single bus to travel the whole loop of the route. Then
column6: the bus 1 starts moving at time 0
column7: the bus 2 starts at time T\xe2\x80\x89/\xe2\x80\x89m
column8: the bus 3 starts at time 2T\xe2\x80\x89/\xe2\x80\x89m
column9: and so on; finally
column10: the bus m starts moving at time (m\xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x891)T\xe2\x80\x89/\xe2\x80\x89m. Thus
column11: all intervals between pairs of consecutive buses (including the interval between the last and the first bus) are equal.Buses can communicate with each other via wireless transmitters of equal power. If the transmitters have power D
column12: then only buses within distance D of each other can communicate.The buses are also equipped with a distributed system of schedule tracking. For all buses to stick to the schedule
column13: the system has to synchronize the necessary data between all buses from time to time. At the moment of synchronization
column14: the bus 1 communicates with the bus 2
column15: the bus 2ï¿½\xe2\x80\x94 with bus 3
column16: and so on; also
column17: the bus m communicates with the bus 1.As a research employee
column18: you are tasked with finding the smallest value of D such that it is possible to find a time moment to perform synchronization once all buses have started moving." 3100

column2: dp" "Andryusha has found a perplexing arcade machine. The machine is a vertically adjusted board divided into square cells. The board has w columns numbered from 1 to w from left to right
column3: and h rows numbered from 1 to h from the bottom to the top.Further
column4: there are barriers in some of board rows. There are n barriers in total
column5: and i-th of them occupied the cells li through ri of the row ui. Andryusha recollects well that no two barriers share the same row. Furthermore
column6: no row is completely occupied with a barrier
column7: that is
column8: at least one cell in each row is free.The player can throw a marble to any column of the machine from above. A marble falls downwards until it encounters a barrier
column9: or falls through the bottom of the board. A marble disappears once it encounters a barrier but is replaced by two more marbles immediately to the left and to the right of the same barrier. In a situation when the barrier is at an edge of the board
column10: both marbles appear next to the barrier at the side opposite to the edge. More than one marble can occupy the same place of the board
column11: without obstructing each other\'s movement. Ultimately
column12: all marbles are bound to fall from the bottom of the machine.  Examples of marble-barrier interaction. Peculiarly
column13: sometimes marbles can go through barriers as if they were free cells. That is so because the barriers are in fact alive
column14: and frightened when a marble was coming at them from a very high altitude. More specifically
column15: if a marble falls towards the barrier i from relative height more than si (that is
column16: it started its fall strictly higher than ui\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x89si)
column17: then the barrier evades the marble. If a marble is thrown from the top of the board
column18: it is considered to appear at height (h\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x891).Andryusha remembers to have thrown a marble once in each of the columns. Help him find the total number of marbles that came down at the bottom of the machine. Since the answer may be large
column19: print it modulo 109\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x897." 2700

column8: no pair of roads shares the starting and the destination towns along with their types simultaneously.The friends are now located in the town 1 and are planning the travel route. Axel enjoys walking
column9: while Marston prefers biking. In order to choose a route diverse and equally interesting for both friends
column10: they have agreed upon the following procedure for choosing the road types during the travel: The route starts with a pedestrian route. Suppose that a beginning of the route is written in a string s of letters P (pedestrain road) and B (biking road). Then
column11: the string  is appended to s
column12: where  stands for the string s with each character changed to opposite (that is
column13: all pedestrian roads changed to bike roads
column14: and vice versa).In the first few steps the route will look as follows: P
column15: PB
column16: PBBP
column17: PBBPBPPB
column18: PBBPBPPBBPPBPBBP
column19: and so on.After that the friends start travelling from the town 1 via Bitlandian roads
column20: choosing the next road according to the next character of their route type each time. If it is impossible to choose the next road
column21: the friends terminate their travel and fly home instead.Help the friends to find the longest possible route that can be travelled along roads of Bitland according to the road types choosing procedure described above. If there is such a route with more than 1018 roads in it
column22: print -1 instead." 2400

column3: graphs" "The evil Bumbershoot corporation produces clones for gruesome experiments in a vast underground lab. On one occasion
column4: the corp cloned a boy Andryusha who was smarter than his comrades. Immediately Andryusha understood that something fishy was going on there. He rallied fellow clones to go on a feud against the evil corp
column5: and they set out to find an exit from the lab. The corp had to reduce to destroy the lab complex.The lab can be pictured as a connected graph with n vertices and m edges. k clones of Andryusha start looking for an exit in some of the vertices. Each clone can traverse any edge once per second. Any number of clones are allowed to be at any vertex simultaneously. Each clone is allowed to stop looking at any time moment
column6: but he must look at his starting vertex at least. The exit can be located at any vertex of the lab
column7: hence each vertex must be visited by at least one clone.Each clone can visit at most  vertices before the lab explodes.Your task is to choose starting vertices and searching routes for the clones. Each route can have at most  vertices." 2100

column14: or

column22: it is possible that some club have short name ""DIN""
column23: where ""DI"" are the first two letters of the team\'s name
column24: and ""N"" is the first letter of hometown\'s name. Of course

column26: report that. If there are multiple answer

column28: then Innokenty will formally think that only one of these options is chosen." 1900

column1: 780A "Andryusha and Socks" implementation "Andryusha is an orderly boy and likes to keep things in their place.Today he faced a problem to put his socks in the wardrobe. He has n distinct pairs of socks which are initially in a bag. The pairs are numbered from 1 to n. Andryusha wants to put paired socks together and put them in the wardrobe. He takes the socks one by one from the bag
column2: and for each sock he looks whether the pair of this sock has been already took out of the bag
column3: or not. If not (that means the pair of this sock is still in the bag)
column4: he puts the current socks on the table in front of him. Otherwise
column5: he puts both socks from the pair to the wardrobe.Andryusha remembers the order in which he took the socks from the bag. Can you tell him what is the maximum number of socks that were on the table at the same time?" 800

column2: math" "In Berland each high school student is characterized by academic performance \xe2\x80\x94 integer value between 1 and 5.In high school 0xFF there are two groups of pupils: the group A and the group B. Each group consists of exactly n students. An academic performance of each student is known \xe2\x80\x94 integer value between 1 and 5.The school director wants to redistribute students between groups so that each of the two groups has the same number of students whose academic performance is equal to 1
column3: the same number of students whose academic performance is 2 and so on. In other words
column4: the purpose of the school director is to change the composition of groups
column5: so that for each value of academic performance the numbers of students in both groups are equal.To achieve this
column6: there is a plan to produce a series of exchanges of students between groups. During the single exchange the director selects one student from the class A and one student of class B. After that
column7: they both change their groups.Print the least number of exchanges
column8: in order to achieve the desired equal numbers of students for each academic performance." 1000

column2: sortings "Boris really likes numbers and even owns a small shop selling interesting numbers. He has n decimal numbers Bi. Cost of the number in his shop is equal to the sum of costs of its digits. You are given the values cd

column8: the resulting number is added to all numbers Bi in Boris\' collection. He uses the artifact exactly once.What is the maximum cost of the collection Boris can achieve after using the artifact?" 3000

column6: trees" "Peterson loves to learn new languages
column7: but his favorite hobby is making new ones. Language is a set of words
column8: and word is a sequence of lowercase Latin letters.Peterson makes new language every morning. It is difficult task to store the whole language
column9: so Peterson have invented new data structure for storing his languages which is called broom. Broom is rooted tree with edges marked with letters. Initially broom is represented by the only vertexï¿½\xe2\x80\x94 the root of the broom. When Peterson wants to add new word to the language he stands at the root and processes the letters of new word one by one. Consider that Peterson stands at the vertex u. If there is an edge from u marked with current letter
column10: Peterson goes through this edge. Otherwise Peterson adds new edge from u to the new vertex v
column11: marks it with the current letter and goes through the new edge. Size of broom is the number of vertices in it.In the evening after working day Peterson can\'t understand the language he made this morning. It is too difficult for bored Peterson and he tries to make it simpler. Simplification of the language is the process of erasing some letters from some words of this language. Formally
column12: Peterson takes some positive integer p and erases p-th letter from all the words of this language having length at least p. Letters in words are indexed starting by 1. Peterson considers that simplification should change at least one word
column13: i.e. there has to be at least one word of length at least p. Peterson tries to make his language as simple as possible
column14: so he wants to choose p such that the size of the broom for his simplified language is as small as possible.Peterson is pretty annoyed with this task so he asks you for help. Write a program to find the smallest possible size of the broom and integer p." 2500

His goal is to stop his sister at some point and continue removing by himself to get the word p. Since Nastya likes this activity

Then both players name the digits written on their cards one by one. If two digits are not equal
column5: then the player
column6: whose digit is smaller gets a flick (knock in the forehead usually made with a forefinger) from the other player. For example
column8: Sherlock\'s card is 123 and Moriarty\'s card has number 321
column9: first Sherlock names 1 and Moriarty names 3 so Sherlock gets a flick. Then they both digit 2 so no one gets a flick. Finally
column10: Sherlock names 3
column11: while Moriarty names 1 and gets a flick.Of course

column13: while Moriary
column14: as a true villain

column19: 3 and get no flicks at all
column20: or he can name 2
column21: 3 and 1 to give Sherlock two flicks.Your goal is to find out the minimum possible number of flicks Moriarty will get (no one likes flicks) and the maximum possible number of flicks Sherlock can get from Moriarty. Note
column22: that these two goals are different and the optimal result may be obtained by using different strategies." 1300

column3: math" "Bomboslav likes to look out of the window in his room and watch lads outside playing famous shell game. The game is played by two persons: operator and player. Operator takes three similar opaque shells and places a ball beneath one of them. Then he shuffles the shells by swapping some pairs and the player has to guess the current position of the ball.Bomboslav noticed that guys are not very inventive
column4: so the operator always swaps the left shell with the middle one during odd moves (first
column5: third
column6: fifth
column7: etc.) and always swaps the middle shell with the right one during even moves (second
column8: fourth
column9: etc.).Let\'s number shells from 0 to 2 from left to right. Thus the left shell is assigned number 0
column10: the middle shell is 1 and the right shell is 2. Bomboslav has missed the moment when the ball was placed beneath the shell
column11: but he knows that exactly n movements were made by the operator and the ball was under shell x at the end. Now he wonders
column12: what was the initial position of the ball?" 1000

column3: dp "Sherlock found a piece of encrypted data which he thinks will be useful to catch Moriarty. The encrypted data consists of two integer l and r. He noticed that these integers were in hexadecimal form.He takes each of the integers from l to r

column5: he lists the digits as 1
column7: \xe2\x80\x894.  Then he sums respective powers of two for each digit listed in the step above. Like in the above example sum\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x8921\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x8920\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x8924\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x891910. column1: 775A "University Schedule" "*special problem" "In this problem your task is to come up with a week schedule of classes in university for professors and student groups. Consider that there are 6 educational days in week and maximum number of classes per educational day is 7 (classes numerated from 1 to 7 for each educational day).It is known that in university n students study
column2: m professors work and there are a classrooms for conducting classes. Also you have two-dimensional array with n\xe2\x80\x89\xc3\x97\xe2\x80\x89m size which contains the following information. The number which stays in i-th row and j-th column equals to the number of classes which professor j must conduct with the group i in a single week. The schedule which you output must satisfy to array described above.There are several other conditions for schedule. Single professor can not conduct more than one class. Similarly
column3: single student group can not be on more than one class at the same time.Let define a fatigue function for professors and student groups. Call this function f.To single professor fatigue calculated in the following way. Let look on classes which this professor must conduct in each of the 6-th educational days. Let x be the number of class which professor will firstly conduct in day i and let y \xe2\x80\x94 the last class for this professor. Then the value (2\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x89y\xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x89x\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x891)\xc2\xb7(2\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x89y\xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x89x\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x891) must be added to professor\'s fatigue. If professor has no classes in day i
column4: nothing is added to professor\'s fatigue. For single student group fatigue is calculated similarly. Lets look at classes of this group in each of the 6 educational days. Let x be the number of first class for this group on day i and let y \xe2\x80\x94 the last class for this group. Then the value (2\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x89y\xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x89x\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x891)\xc2\xb7(2\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x89y\xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x89x\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x891) must be added to this group\'s fatigue. If student group has no classes in day i
column5: nothing is added to group\'s fatigue.So the value of function f equals to total {fatigue} for all n student groups and for all m professors.Your task is to come up with such a schedule which minimizes the value of function f.Jury prepared some solution of this problem. For each test you will get a certain number of points. It equals to result of division of the value of function f from the jury solution by the value of function f for schedule which your program output (i. e. the smaller value of {fatigue} function your program find the more points you will get)
column6: multiplied by 100. In the other words if the value of f for jury solution equals to p and for your solution \xe2\x80\x94 to q
column7: you will get 100\xc2\xb7p\xe2\x80\x89/\xe2\x80\x89q points (note
column8: that the number of points is a real number). The points will be added together for all tests. The goal is to score as many points as possible." 2900

column2: binary search" "Polycarp\'s workday lasts exactly n minutes. He loves chocolate bars and can eat one bar in one minute. In other minutes he can either eat or not eat one chocolate bar. It is guaranteed

Then the break time is equal to y\xe2\x88\x92x\xe2\x88\x921 minutes. It is not necessary for Polycarp to eat all bars he has." 2000

column6: number theory" "Test data generation is not an easy task! Often
column7: generating big random test cases is not enough to ensure thorough testing of solutions for correctness.For example
column8: consider a problem from an old Codeforces round. Its input format looks roughly as follows:The first line contains a single integer n (1\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x89\xa4\xe2\x80\x89n\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x89\xa4\xe2\x80\x89maxn)ï¿½\xe2\x80\x94 the size of the set. The second line contains n distinct integers a1
column11: \xe2\x80\x89an (1\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x89\xa4\xe2\x80\x89ai\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x89\xa4\xe2\x80\x89maxa)ï¿½\xe2\x80\x94 the elements of the set in increasing order.If you don\'t pay attention to the problem solution
column12: it looks fairly easy to generate a good test case for this problem. Let n\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x89maxn
column13: take random distinct ai from 1 to maxa
column14: sort them... Soon you understand that it\'s not that easy.Here is the actual problem solution. Let g be the greatest common divisor of a1
column17: \xe2\x80\x89an. Let x\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x89an\xe2\x80\x89/\xe2\x80\x89g\xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x89n. Then the correct solution outputs ""Alice"" if x is odd
column18: and ""Bob"" if x is even.Consider two wrong solutions to this problem which differ from the correct one only in the formula for calculating x.The first wrong solution calculates x as x\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x89an\xe2\x80\x89/\xe2\x80\x89g (without subtracting n).The second wrong solution calculates x as x\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x89an\xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x89n (without dividing by g).A test case is interesting if it makes both wrong solutions output an incorrect answer.Given maxn
column19: maxa and q
column20: find the number of interesting test cases satisfying the constraints
column21: and output it modulo q." 3400

column2: sortings" "It\'s well-known that blog posts are an important part of Codeforces platform. Every blog post has a global characteristic changing over timeï¿½\xe2\x80\x94 its community rating. A newly created blog post\'s community rating is 0. Codeforces users may visit the blog post page and rate it
column3: changing its community rating by +1 or -1.Consider the following model of Codeforces users\' behavior. The i-th user has his own estimated blog post rating denoted by an integer ai. When a user visits a blog post page
column4: he compares his estimated blog post rating to its community rating. If his estimated rating is higher
column5: he rates the blog post with +1 (thus
column6: the blog post\'s community rating increases by 1). If his estimated rating is lower
column7: he rates the blog post with -1 (decreasing its community rating by 1). If the estimated rating and the community rating are equal
column8: user doesn\'t rate the blog post at all (in this case we\'ll say that user rates the blog post for 0). In any case
column9: after this procedure user closes the blog post page and never opens it again.Consider a newly created blog post with the initial community rating of 0. For each of n Codeforces users
column10: numbered from 1 to n
column11: his estimated blog post rating ai is known.For each k from 1 to n
column12: inclusive
column13: the following question is asked. Let users with indices from 1 to k
column14: in some order
column15: visit the blog post page
column16: rate the blog post and close the page. Each user opens the blog post only after the previous user closes it. What could be the maximum possible community rating of the blog post after these k visits?" 3000

column3: shortest paths" "In the country of Never
column4: there are n cities and a well-developed road system. There is exactly one bidirectional road between every pair of cities
column5: thus
column6: there are as many as  roads! No two roads intersect
column7: and no road passes through intermediate cities. The art of building tunnels and bridges has been mastered by Neverians.An independent committee has evaluated each road of Never with a positive integer called the perishability of the road. The lower the road\'s perishability is
column8: the more pleasant it is to drive through this road.It\'s the year of transport in Never. It has been decided to build a museum of transport in one of the cities
column9: and to set a single signpost directing to some city (not necessarily the one with the museum) in each of the other cities. The signposts must satisfy the following important condition: if any Neverian living in a city without the museum starts travelling from that city following the directions of the signposts
column10: then this person will eventually arrive in the city with the museum.Neverians are incredibly positive-minded. If a Neverian travels by a route consisting of several roads
column11: he considers the perishability of the route to be equal to the smallest perishability of all the roads in this route.The government of Never has not yet decided where to build the museum
column12: so they consider all n possible options. The most important is the sum of perishabilities of the routes to the museum city from all the other cities of Never
column13: if the travelers strictly follow the directions of the signposts. The government of Never cares about their citizens
column14: so they want to set the signposts in a way which minimizes this sum. Help them determine the minimum possible sum for all n possible options of the city where the museum can be built." 2700

column4: math" "It can be shown that any positive integer x can be uniquely represented as x\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x891\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x892\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x894\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x89...\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x892k\xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x891\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x89r
column5: where k and r are integers
column7: 0\xe2\x80\x89<\xe2\x80\x89r\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x89\xa4\xe2\x80\x892k. Let\'s call that representation prairie partition of x.For example
column8: the prairie partitions of 12
column13: 1\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x891. Alice took a sequence of positive integers (possibly with repeating elements)
column14: replaced every element with the sequence of summands in its prairie partition
column15: arranged the resulting numbers in non-decreasing order and gave them to Borys. Now Borys wonders how many elements Alice\'s original sequence could contain. Find all possible options!" 2200

column2: greedy" "Vasya and Petya take part in a Codeforces round. The round lasts for two hours and contains five problems.For this round the dynamic problem scoring is used. If you were lucky not to participate in any Codeforces round with dynamic problem scoring
column3: here is what it means. The maximum point value of the problem depends on the ratio of the number of participants who solved the problem to the total number of round participants. Everyone who made at least one submission is considered to be participating in the round.Pay attention to the range bounds. For example
column4: if 40 people are taking part in the round
column5: and 10 of them solve a particular problem
column6: then the solvers fraction is equal to 1\xe2\x80\x89/\xe2\x80\x894
column7: and the problem\'s maximum point value is equal to 1500.If the problem\'s maximum point value is equal to x
column8: then for each whole minute passed from the beginning of the contest to the moment of the participant\'s correct submission
column9: the participant loses x\xe2\x80\x89/\xe2\x80\x89250 points. For example
column10: if the problem\'s maximum point value is 2000
column11: and the participant submits a correct solution to it 40 minutes into the round
column12: this participant will be awarded with 2000\xc2\xb7(1\xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x8940\xe2\x80\x89/\xe2\x80\x89250)\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x891680 points for this problem.There are n participants in the round
column13: including Vasya and Petya. For each participant and each problem
column14: the number of minutes which passed between the beginning of the contest and the submission of this participant to this problem is known. It\'s also possible that this participant made no submissions to this problem.With two seconds until the end of the round
column15: all participants\' submissions have passed pretests
column16: and not a single hack attempt has been made. Vasya believes that no more submissions or hack attempts will be made in the remaining two seconds
column17: and every submission will pass the system testing.Unfortunately
column18: Vasya is a cheater. He has registered 109\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x897 new accounts for the round. Now Vasya can submit any of his solutions from these new accounts in order to change the maximum point values of the problems. Vasya can also submit any wrong solutions to any problems. Note that Vasya can not submit correct solutions to the problems he hasn\'t solved.Vasya seeks to score strictly more points than Petya in the current round. A compressed sequence of sequence c of length n is a sequence p of length n

column10: for the sequence c\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x89[250
column14: \xe2\x80\x8950] the compressed sequence will be p\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x89[4

column19: the compressed sequence contains all integers from 1 to n inclusively.Help Dasha to find any sequence b for which the calculated compressed sequence of sequence c is correct." 1700

column3: implementation" "After overcoming the stairs Dasha came to classes. She needed to write a password to begin her classes. The password is a string of length n which satisfies the following requirements:  There is at least one digit in the string

column5: There is at least one of three listed symbols in the string: \'#\'
column7: \'&\'.   Considering that these are programming classes it is not easy to write the password.For each character of the password we have a fixed string of length m
column8: on each of these n strings there is a pointer on some character. The i-th character displayed on the screen is the pointed character in the i-th string. Initially
column9: all pointers are on characters with indexes 1 in the corresponding strings (all positions are numbered starting from one).During one operation Dasha can move a pointer in one string one character to the left or to the right. Strings are cyclic
column10: it means that when we move the pointer which is on the character with index 1 to the left
column11: it moves to the character with the index m
column12: and when we move it to the right from the position m it moves to the position 1.You need to determine the minimum number of operations necessary to make the string displayed on the screen a valid password." 1500

column3: number theory" "Consider the following grammar: <expression> ::= <term> | <expression> \'+\' <term> <term> ::= <number> | <number> \'-\' <number> | <number> \'(\' <expression> \')\' <number> ::= <pos_digit> | <number> <digit> <digit> ::= \'0\' | <pos_digit> <pos_digit> ::= \'1\' | \'2\' | \'3\' | \'4\' | \'5\' | \'6\' | \'7\' | \'8\' | \'9\'This grammar describes a number in decimal system using the following rules: <number> describes itself
column4: <number>-<number> (l-r
column5: l\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x89\xa4\xe2\x80\x89r) describes integer which is concatenation of all integers from l to r
column6: written without leading zeros. For example
column7: 8-11 describes 891011
column8: <number>(<expression>) describes integer which is concatenation of <number> copies of integer described by <expression>
column9: <expression>+<term> describes integer which is concatenation of integers described by <expression> and <term>.For example
column10: 2(2-4+1)+2(2(17)) describes the integer 2341234117171717.You are given an expression in the given grammar. Print the integer described by it modulo 109\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x897." 3400

column4: string suffix structures" "Julia is conducting an experiment in her lab. She placed several luminescent bacterial colonies in a horizontal testtube. Different types of bacteria can be distinguished by the color of light they emit. Julia marks types of bacteria with small Latin letters ""a""
column6: ""z"".The testtube is divided into n consecutive regions. Each region is occupied by a single colony of a certain bacteria type at any given moment. Hence
column7: the population of the testtube at any moment can be described by a string of n Latin characters.Sometimes a colony can decide to conquer another colony in one of the adjacent regions. When that happens
column8: the attacked colony is immediately eliminated and replaced by a colony of the same type as the attacking colony
column9: while the attacking colony keeps its type. Note that a colony can only attack its neighbours within the boundaries of the testtube. At any moment
column10: at most one attack can take place.For example
column11: consider a testtube with population ""babb"". There are six options for an attack that may happen next: the first colony attacks the second colony (1\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x86\x92\xe2\x80\x892)
column12: the resulting population is ""bbbb""; 2\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x86\x92\xe2\x80\x891
column13: the result is ""aabb""; 2\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x86\x92\xe2\x80\x893
column14: the result is ""baab""; 3\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x86\x92\xe2\x80\x892
column15: the result is ""bbbb"" (note that the result is the same as the first option); 3\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x86\x92\xe2\x80\x894 or 4\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x86\x92\xe2\x80\x893
column16: the population does not change.The pattern of attacks is rather unpredictable. Julia is now wondering how many different configurations of bacteria in the testtube she can obtain after a sequence of attacks takes place (it is possible that no attacks will happen at all). Since this number can be large
column17: find it modulo 109\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x897." 2400

column1: 756C "Nikita and stack" "data structures" "Nikita has a stack. A stack in this problem is a data structure that supports two operations. Operation push(x) puts an integer x on the top of the stack
column2: and operation pop() deletes the top integer from the stack
column3: i.ï¿½e. the last added. If the stack is empty
column4: then the operation pop() does nothing.Nikita made m operations with the stack but forgot them. Now Nikita wants to remember them. He remembers them one by one
column5: on the i-th step he remembers an operation he made pi-th. In other words
column6: he remembers the operations in order of some permutation p1
column9: \xe2\x80\x89pm. After each step Nikita wants to know what is the integer on the top of the stack after performing the operations he have already remembered
column10: in the corresponding order. Help him!" 2200

column2: dp" "A new innovative ticketing systems for public transport is introduced in Bytesburg. Now there is a single travel card for all transport. To make a trip a passenger scan his card and then he is charged according to the fare.The fare is constructed in the following manner. There are three types of tickets:   a ticket for one trip costs 20 byteland rubles
column3: a ticket for 90 minutes costs 50 byteland rubles
column4: a ticket for one day (1440 minutes) costs 120 byteland rubles. Note that a ticket for x minutes activated at time t can be used for trips started in time range from t to t\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x89x\xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x891
column5: inclusive. Assume that all trips take exactly one minute.To simplify the choice for the passenger
column6: the system automatically chooses the optimal tickets. After each trip starts
column7: the system analyses all the previous trips and the current trip and chooses a set of tickets for these trips with a minimum total cost. Let the minimum total cost of tickets to cover all trips from the first to the current is a
column8: and the total sum charged before is b. Then the system charges the passenger the sum a\xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x89b.You have to write a program that
column9: for given trips made by a passenger
column10: calculates the sum the passenger is charged after each trip." 1600

column2: dfs and similar" "Pavel cooks barbecue. There are n skewers
column3: they lay on a brazier in a row
column4: each on one of n positions. Pavel wants each skewer to be cooked some time in every of n positions in two directions: in the one it was directed originally and in the reversed direction.Pavel has a plan: a permutation p and a sequence b1
column7: \xe2\x80\x89bn
column8: consisting of zeros and ones. Each second Pavel move skewer on position i to position pi
column9: and if bi equals 1 then he reverses it. So he hope that every skewer will visit every position in both directions.Unfortunately
column10: not every pair of permutation p and sequence b suits Pavel. What is the minimum total number of elements in the given permutation p and the given sequence b he needs to change so that every skewer will visit each of 2n placements? Note that after changing the permutation should remain a permutation as well.There is no problem for Pavel
column11: if some skewer visits some of the placements several times before he ends to cook. In other words
column12: a permutation p and a sequence b suit him if there is an integer k (k\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x89\xa5\xe2\x80\x892n)
column13: so that after k seconds each skewer visits each of the 2n placements.It can be shown that some suitable pair of permutation p and sequence b exists for any n." 1700

Before the first turn all the field cells are empty. The two players take turns placing their signs into empty cells (the first player places Xs
column3: the second player places Os). The player who places Xs goes first
column4: the another one goes second. The winner is the player who first gets three of his signs in a row next to each other (horizontal
column5: vertical or diagonal)." 1100

column3: implementation" "One spring day on his way to university Lesha found an array A. Lesha likes to split arrays into several parts. This time Lesha decided to split the array A into several
column4: possibly one

column3: interactive" "The only difference from the previous problem is the constraint on the number of requests. In this problem your program should guess the answer doing at most 7 requests.This problem is a little bit unusual. Here you are to implement an interaction with a testing system. That means that you can make queries and get responses in the online mode. Please be sure to use the stream flushing operation after each query\'s output in order not to leave part of your output in some buffer. For example
column4: in C++ you\'ve got to use the fflush(stdout) function
column5: in Java \xe2\x80\x94 call System.out.flush()
column6: and in Pascal \xe2\x80\x94 flush(output).Bulls and Cows (also known as Cows and Bulls or Pigs and Bulls or Bulls and Cleots) is an old code-breaking paper and pencil game for two players
column7: predating the similar commercially marketed board game Mastermind.On a sheet of paper
column8: the first player thinks a secret string. This string consists only of digits and has the length 4. The digits in the string must be all different
column9: no two or more equal digits are allowed.Then the second player tries to guess his opponent\'s string. For every guess the first player gives the number of matches. If the matching digits are on their right positions
column10: they are ""bulls""
column11: if on different positions
column12: they are ""cows"". Thus a response is a pair of numbers \xe2\x80\x94 the number of ""bulls"" and the number of ""cows"". A try can contain equal digits.More formally
column13: let\'s the secret string is s and the second player are trying to guess it with a string x. The number of ""bulls"" is a number of such positions i (1\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x89\xa4\xe2\x80\x89i\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x89\xa4\xe2\x80\x894) where s[i]\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x89x[i]. The number of ""cows"" is a number of such digits c that s contains c in the position i (i.e. s[i]\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x89c)
column14: x contains c
column15: but x[i]\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x89\xa0\xe2\x80\x89c.For example
column16: the secret string is ""0427""
column17: the opponent\'s try is ""0724""
column18: then the answer is 2 bulls and 2 cows (the bulls are ""0"" and ""2""
column19: the cows are ""4"" and ""7""). If the secret string is ""0123""
column20: the opponent\'s try is ""0330""
column21: then the answer is 1 bull and 1 cow.In this problem you are to guess the string s that the system has chosen. You only know that the chosen string consists of 4 distinct digits.You can make queries to the testing system
column22: each query is the output of a single 4-digit string. The answer to the query is the number of bulls and number of cows. If the system\'s response equals ""4 0""
column23: that means the interaction with your problem is over and the program must terminate. That is possible for two reasons \xe2\x80\x94 the program either guessed the number x or made an invalid action (for example
column24: printed letters instead of digits).Your program is allowed to do at most 7 queries.You can hack solutions of other participants providing a 4-digit string containing distinct digits \xe2\x80\x94 the secret string." 2500

column3: math "Santa Claus has n candies

column1: 750H "New Year and Snowy Grid" "dfs and similar
column3: graphs
column4: interactive" "Pay attention to the output section below
column5: where you will see the information about flushing the output.Bearland is a grid with h rows and w columns. Rows are numbered 1 through h from top to bottom. Columns are numbered 1 through w from left to right. Every cell is either allowed (denoted by \'.\' in the input) or permanently blocked (denoted by \'#\').Bearland is a cold land
column6: where heavy snow often makes travelling harder. Every day a few allowed cells are temporarily blocked by snow. Note
column7: that this block works only on this particular day and next day any of these cells might be allowed again (unless there is another temporarily block).It\'s possible to move directly between two cells only if they share a side and none of them is permanently or temporarily blocked.Limak is a little polar bear who lives in Bearland. His house is at the top left cell
column8: while his school is at the bottom right cell. Every day Limak should first go from his house to the school and then return back to his house. Since he gets bored easily
column9: he doesn\'t want to visit the same cell twice on one day
column10: except for the cell with his house
column11: where he starts and ends. If Limak can reach a school and return home avoiding revisiting cells
column12: he calls a day interesting.There are q days you must process
column13: one after another. For each of these days you should check if it\'s interesting and print ""YES"" or ""NO"" on a separate line. In order to be able to read the description of the next day you should print the answer for the previous one and flush the output.It\'s guaranteed that a day with no cells temporarily blocked by snow would be interesting. It\'s also guaranteed that cells with Limak\'s house and school are never blocked (neither permanently or temporarily)." 3500

column3: combinatorics
column4: dp" "The New Year tree is an infinite perfect binary tree rooted in the node 1. Each node v has two children: nodes indexed (2\xc2\xb7v) and (2\xc2\xb7v\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x891).  Polar bears love decorating the New Year tree and Limak is no exception. As he is only a little bear
column5: he was told to decorate only one simple path between some pair of nodes. Though he was given an opportunity to pick the pair himself! Now he wants to know the number of unordered pairs of indices (u
column7: such that the sum of indices of all nodes along the simple path between u and v (including endpoints) is equal to s. Can you help him and count this value?" 3200

column3: interactive
column4: trees" "This is an interactive problem. In the interaction section below you will find the information about flushing the output.The New Year tree of height h is a perfect binary tree with vertices numbered 1 through 2h\xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x891 in some order. In this problem we assume that h is at least 2. The drawing below shows one example New Year tree of height 3:  Polar bears love decorating the New Year tree and Limak is no exception. To decorate the tree
column5: he must first find its root
column6: i.e. a vertex with exactly two neighbours (assuming that h\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x89\xa5\xe2\x80\x892). It won\'t be easy because Limak is a little bear and he doesn\'t even see the whole tree. Can you help him?There are t testcases. In each testcase
column7: you should first read h from the input. Then you can ask at most 16 questions of format ""? x"" (without quotes)
column8: where x is an integer between 1 and 2h\xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x891
column9: inclusive. As a reply you will get the list of neighbours of vertex x (more details in the ""Interaction"" section below). For example
column10: for a tree on the drawing above after asking ""? 1"" you would get a response with 3 neighbours: 4
column11: 5 and 7. Your goal is to find the index of the root y and print it in the format ""! y"". You will be able to read h for a next testcase only after printing the answer in a previous testcase and flushing the output.Each tree is fixed from the beginning and it doesn\'t change during your questions." 2800

column3: dp
column4: matrices" "A string t is called nice if a string ""2017"" occurs in t as a subsequence but a string ""2016"" doesn\'t occur in t as a subsequence. For example
column5: strings ""203434107"" and ""9220617"" are nice
column6: while strings ""20016""
column7: ""1234"" and ""20167"" aren\'t nice.The ugliness of a string is the minimum possible number of characters to remove
column8: in order to obtain a nice string. If it\'s impossible to make a string nice by removing characters
column9: its ugliness is \xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x891.Limak has a string s of length n
column10: with characters indexed 1 through n. He asks you q queries. In the i-th query you should compute and print the ugliness of a substring (continuous subsequence) of s starting at the index ai and ending at the index bi (inclusive)." 2600

column5: implementation" "One tradition of welcoming the New Year is launching fireworks into the sky. Usually a launched firework flies vertically upward for some period of time
column6: then explodes
column7: splitting into several parts flying in different directions. Sometimes those parts also explode after some period of time
column8: splitting into even more parts
column9: and so on.Limak
column10: who lives in an infinite grid
column11: has a single firework. The behaviour of the firework is described with a recursion depth n and a duration for each level of recursion t1
column14: \xe2\x80\x89tn. Once Limak launches the firework in some cell
column15: the firework starts moving upward. After covering t1 cells (including the starting cell)
column16: it explodes and splits into two parts
column17: each moving in the direction changed by 45 degrees (see the pictures below for clarification). So
column18: one part moves in the top-left direction
column19: while the other one moves in the top-right direction. Each part explodes again after covering t2 cells
column20: splitting into two parts moving in directions again changed by 45 degrees. The process continues till the n-th level of recursion
column21: when all 2n\xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x891 existing parts explode and disappear without creating new parts. After a few levels of recursion
column22: it\'s possible that some parts will be at the same place and at the same timeï¿½\xe2\x80\x94 it is allowed and such parts do not crash.Before launching the firework
column23: Limak must make sure that nobody stands in cells which will be visited at least once by the firework. Can you count the number of those cells?" 1900

column3: math" "Every Codeforces user has rating
column4: described with one integer
column5: possibly negative or zero. Users are divided into two divisions. The first division is for users with rating 1900 or higher. Those with rating 1899 or lower belong to the second division. In every contest
column6: according to one\'s performance
column7: his or her rating changes by some value
column8: possibly negative or zero.Limak competed in n contests in the year 2016. He remembers that in the i-th contest he competed in the division di (i.e. he belonged to this division just before the start of this contest) and his rating changed by ci just after the contest. Note that negative ci denotes the loss of rating.What is the maximum possible rating Limak can have right now
column9: after all n contests? If his rating may be arbitrarily big
column10: print ""Infinity"". If there is no scenario matching the given information
column11: print ""Impossible""." 1600

column2: implementation "In this problem we assume the Earth to be a completely round ball and its surface a perfect sphere. The length of the equator and any meridian is considered to be exactly 40\xe2\x80\x89000 kilometers. Thus
column3: travelling from North Pole to South Pole or vice versa takes exactly 20\xe2\x80\x89000 kilometers.Limak
column4: a polar bear
column5: lives on the North Pole. Close to the New Year
column6: he helps somebody with delivering packages all around the world. Instead of coordinates of places to visit
column7: Limak got a description how he should move
column8: assuming that he starts from the North Pole. The description consists of n parts. In the i-th part of his journey
column9: Limak should move ti kilometers in the direction represented by a string diri that is one of: ""North""
column10: ""South""
column11: ""West""
column12: ""East"".Limak isn\xe2\x80\x99t sure whether the description is valid. You must help him to check the following conditions:  If at any moment of time (before any of the instructions or while performing one of them) Limak is on the North Pole
column13: he can move only to the South.  If at any moment of time (before any of the instructions or while performing one of them) Limak is on the South Pole

column3: two pointers" "There are n employees in Alternative Cake Manufacturing (ACM). They are now voting on some very important question and the leading world media are trying to predict the outcome of the vote.Each of the employees belongs to one of two fractions: depublicans or remocrats
column4: and these two fractions have opposite opinions on what should be the outcome of the vote. The voting procedure is rather complicated:   Each of n employees makes a statement. They make statements one by one starting from employees 1 and finishing with employee n. If at the moment when it\'s time for the i-th employee to make a statement he no longer has the right to vote
column5: he just skips his turn (and no longer takes part in this voting).  When employee makes a statement
column6: he can do nothing or declare that one of the other employees no longer has a right to vote. It\'s allowed to deny from voting people who already made the statement or people who are only waiting to do so. If someone is denied from voting he no longer participates in the voting till the very end.  When all employees are done with their statements
column7: the procedure repeats: again
column8: each employees starting from 1 and finishing with n who are still eligible to vote make their statements.  The process repeats until there is only one employee eligible to vote remaining and he determines the outcome of the whole voting. Of course
column9: he votes for the decision suitable for his fraction. You know the order employees are going to vote and that they behave optimal (and they also know the order and who belongs to which fraction). Predict the outcome of the vote." 1500

Let Santa\'s joy be the minimum among all bi\'s.Your task is to find the maximum possible joy Santa can have after he treats everyone with tangerines (or their parts)." 2100

column3: sortings "The winter in Berland lasts n days. For each day we know the forecast for the average air temperature that day. Vasya has a new set of winter tires which allows him to drive safely no more than k days at any average air temperature. After k days of using it (regardless of the temperature of these days) the set of winter tires wears down and cannot be used more. It is not necessary that these k days form a continuous segment of days.Before the first winter day Vasya still uses summer tires. It is possible to drive safely on summer tires any number of days when the average air temperature is non-negative. It is impossible to drive on summer tires at days when the average air temperature is negative. Vasya can change summer tires to winter tires and vice versa at the beginning of any day.Find the minimum number of times Vasya needs to change summer tires to winter tires and vice versa to drive safely during the winter. At the end of the winter the car can be with any set of tires." 1800

column7: ""raabracadab"" and so on.Hongcow is now wondering how many distinct words he can generate by doing the cyclic shift arbitrarily many times. The initial string is also counted." 900

column6: negative or zero. Sponsors placed the gift 1 on the top of the tree. All the other gifts hung on a rope tied to some other gift so that each gift hung on the first gift
column7: possibly with a sequence of ropes and another gifts. Formally
column8: the gifts formed a rooted tree with n vertices.The prize-giving procedure goes in the following way: the participants come to the tree one after another
column9: choose any of the remaining gifts and cut the rope this prize hang on. Note that all the ropes which were used to hang other prizes on the chosen one are not cut. So the contestant gets the chosen gift as well as the all the gifts that hang on it
column10: possibly with a sequence of ropes and another gifts.Our friends

column14: there shouldn\'t be any gift that hang both on the gift chosen by Chloe and on the gift chosen by Vladik. column3: implementation" "Vladik is a competitive programmer. This year he is going to win the International Olympiad in Informatics. But it is not as easy as it sounds: the question Vladik face now is to find the cheapest way to get to the olympiad.Vladik knows n airports. All the airports are located on a straight line. Each airport has unique id from 1 to n
column4: Vladik\'s house is situated next to the airport with id a
column5: and the place of the olympiad is situated next to the airport with id b. It is possible that Vladik\'s house and the place of the olympiad are located near the same airport. To get to the olympiad
column6: Vladik can fly between any pair of airports any number of times
column7: but he has to start his route at the airport a and finish it at the airport b.Each airport belongs to one of two companies. The cost of flight from the airport i to the airport j is zero if both airports belong to the same company
column8: and |i\xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x89j| if they belong to different companies.Print the minimum cost Vladik has to pay to get to the olympiad." 1200

column5: consider the case when the mother has 5 flowers
column6: and their moods are equal to 1

column20: because he is in one of chosen subarrays

column22: because he is in one of chosen subarrays
column23: the third flower adds 1\xc2\xb72\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x892
column24: because he is in two of chosen subarrays
column25: the fourth flower adds 3\xc2\xb72\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x896
column26: because he is in two of chosen subarrays

column2: implementation" "Little girl Alyona is in a shop to buy some copybooks for school. She study four subjects so she wants to have equal number of copybooks for each of the subjects. There are three types of copybook\'s packs in the shop: it is possible to buy one copybook for a rubles
column3: a pack of two copybooks for b rubles
column4: and a pack of three copybooks for c rubles.
